analyzed: natthi yaḥ maraṇa dhammo samānaḥ na bhāyati na santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa ati
translated: ‘There is no one who, subject to death, is not afraid or fearful of death.’”

original: “Atthi, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa;
analyzed: atthi brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammo samānaḥ bhāyati santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa
translated: “There is, brahmin. There is a person who, subject to death, fears it and is troubled by it.

original: atthi pana, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa.
analyzed: atthi pana brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammo samānaḥ na bhāyati na santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa
translated: But there is a person who, subject to death, does not fear it or is not troubled by it.

original: Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammo samānaḥ bhāyati santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa
translated: “And what is the person who, subject to death, fears it and is troubled by it?

original: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco kāmesu avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho.
analyzed: idha brāhmaṇaḥ ekaccaḥ kāmesu a vīta rāgaḥ hoti avigata chandaḥ avigata pemaḥ avigata pipāsaḥ avigata pariḷāhaḥ a vigata taṇhaḥ
translated: There is the case where a certain person is not free from lust, desire, affection, thirst, passion, and craving in regard to sensual pleasures.

original: Tamenaṁ aññataro gāḷho rogātaṅko phusati.
analyzed: tam enam aññataraḥ gāḷhaḥ roga ātaṅkaḥ phusati
translated: Then he falls sick with a certain disease.

original: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa aññatarena gāḷhena roga ātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evam hoti
translated: He thinks, ‘I am now sick with a disease.

original: ‘piyā vata maṁ kāmā jahissanti, piye cāhaṁ kāme jahissāmī’ti.
analyzed: piyāḥ vata mam kāmāḥ jahissanti piye ca aham kāme jahissāmi iti
translated: My dear sensual pleasures are leaving me, and I am leaving my dear sensual pleasures.’

original: So socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṁ kandati, sammohaṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: saḥ socati kilamati paridevati uras tāḷim kandati sammoham āpajjati
translated: He sorrows, grieves, and laments, he weeps beating his breast and becomes distraught.

original: Ayaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa.
analyzed: ayam kho brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammaḥ samānaḥ bhāyati santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa
translated: This is the person who, subject to death, fears it and is troubled by it.

original: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco kāye avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho.
analyzed: puna capara brāhmaṇaḥ idha ekaccaḥ kāye a vīta rāgaḥ hoti avigata chandaḥ avigata pemaḥ avigata pipāsaḥ avigata pariḷāhaḥ a vigata taṇhaḥ
translated: “Again, someone here is not free from lust, desire, affection, thirst, fever, and craving for the body.

original: Tamenaṁ aññataro gāḷho rogātaṅko phusati.
analyzed: tam enam aññataraḥ gāḷhaḥ roga ātaṅkaḥ phusati
translated: Then a severe illness befalls him.

original: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa aññatarena gāḷhena roga ātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evam hoti
translated: When he is afflicted with a severe illness, he thinks:

original: ‘piyo vata maṁ kāyo jahissati, piyañcāhaṁ kāyaṁ jahissāmī’ti.
analyzed: piyaḥ vata mama kāyaḥ jahissati piyam ca aham kāyam jahissāmi iti
translated: ‘I am dear to my body, and my body is dear to me.’

original: So socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṁ kandati, sammohaṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: saḥ socati kilamati paridevati uras tāḷim kandati sammoham āpajjati
translated: He sorrows, grieves, and laments, he weeps beating his breast and becomes distraught.

original: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa.
analyzed: ayam pi kho brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammaḥ samānaḥ bhāyati santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa
translated: This person, subject to death, fears and is in suspense about death.

original: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco akatakalyāṇo hoti akatakusalo akatabhīruttāṇo katapāpo kataluddo katakibbiso.🔽Tamenaṁ aññataro gāḷho rogātaṅko phusati.
analyzed: puna capara brāhmaṇaḥ idha ekaccaḥ akata kalyāṇaḥ hoti akata kusalaḥ akata bhīruttāṇaḥ kata pāpaḥ kata luddaḥ kata kibbisaḥ  tam enam aññataraḥ gāḷhaḥ roga ātaṅkaḥ phusati
translated: “Again, someone here has not done good, wholesome, and skillful deeds, has not avoided wrongdoing, has not taken refuge in the Dhamma, and has not built a spiritual foundation for himself.🔽Then a severe illness befalls him.

original: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa aññatarena gāḷhena roga ātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evam hoti
translated: When he is afflicted with a severe illness, he thinks:

original: ‘akataṁ vata me kalyāṇaṁ, akataṁ kusalaṁ, akataṁ bhīruttāṇaṁ;
analyzed: akatam vata me kalyāṇa akatam kusala akatam bhīruttāṇa
translated: ‘I haven’t done what’s good, I haven’t done what’s skillful, I haven’t done what’s pleasing.

original: kataṁ pāpaṁ, kataṁ luddaṁ, kataṁ kibbisaṁ.
analyzed: katam pāpa katam ludda katam kibbisa
translated: I’ve done what’s bad, I’ve done what’s reckless, I’ve done what’s cruel.

original: Yāvatā, bho, akatakalyāṇānaṁ akatakusalānaṁ akatabhīruttāṇānaṁ katapāpānaṁ kataluddānaṁ katakibbisānaṁ gati taṁ gatiṁ pecca gacchāmī’ti.
analyzed: yāvatā bho a kata kalyāṇānam a kata kusalānam a kata bhīruttāṇānam kata pāpānam kata luddānam kata kibbisānam gati tam gatim pecca gacchāmi iti
translated: Wherever those who haven’t done what’s good, who haven’t done what’s skillful, who haven’t done what’s pleasing, but have done what’s bad, what’s reckless, what’s cruel, go after death, that will be my lot after death.’

original: So socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṁ kandati, sammohaṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: saḥ socati kilamati paridevati uras tāḷim kandati sammoham āpajjati
translated: He sorrows, grieves, & laments, beats his breast, becomes distraught.

original: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa.
analyzed: ayam pi kho brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammaḥ samānaḥ bhāyati santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa
translated: This is the second person who, subject to death, fears & hesitates about death.

original: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco kaṅkhī hoti vicikicchī aniṭṭhaṅgato saddhamme.
analyzed: puna capara brāhmaṇaḥ idha ekaccaḥ kaṅkhī hoti vicikicchī a niṭṭhaṅgataḥ saddhamme
translated: “Then there is the case where a certain person is doubtful, uncertain, undecided, & unconfident about the true Dhamma.

original: Tamenaṁ aññataro gāḷho rogātaṅko phusati.
analyzed: tam enam aññataraḥ gāḷhaḥ roga ātaṅkaḥ phusati
translated: Then he falls prey to a powerful disease.

original: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa aññatarena gāḷhena roga ātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evam hoti
translated: The thought occurs to him:

original: ‘kaṅkhī vatamhi vicikicchī aniṭṭhaṅgato saddhamme’ti.
analyzed: kaṅkhī vatamhi vicikicchī a niṭṭhaṅgataḥ saddhamma iti
translated: ‘I am doubtful, uncertain, undecided, & unconfident about the true Dhamma.’

original: So socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṁ kandati, sammohaṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: saḥ socati kilamati paridevati uras tāḷim kandati sammoham āpajjati
translated: He sorrows, grieves, & laments, beats his breast, becomes distraught.

original: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa.
analyzed: ayam pi kho brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammaḥ samānaḥ bhāyati santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa
translated: This one, though subject to death, is frightened and terrified of death.

original: Ime kho, brāhmaṇa, cattāro maraṇadhammā samānā bhāyanti, santāsaṁ āpajjanti maraṇassa.
analyzed: ime kho brāhmaṇa cattāraḥ maraṇa dhammā samānāḥ bhāyanti santāsam āpajjanti maraṇassa
translated: These four, though subject to death, are frightened and terrified of death.

original: Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammo samānaḥ na bhāyati na santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa
translated: “And what, Brahmin, is the one who, though subject to death, is not frightened or terrified of death?

original: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco kāmesu vītarāgo hoti vigatacchando vigatapemo vigatapipāso vigatapariḷāho vigatataṇho.🔽Tamenaṁ aññataro gāḷho rogātaṅko phusati.
analyzed: idha brāhmaṇaḥ ekaccaḥ kāmesu vīta rāgaḥ hoti vigata chandaḥ vigata pemaḥ vigata pipāsaḥ vigata pariḷāhaḥ vigata taṇhaḥ  tam enam aññataraḥ gāḷhaḥ roga ātaṅkaḥ phusati
translated: Here, Brahmin, someone is free from lust, desire, affection, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.🔽Then some serious disease might invade his body.

original: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa na evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa aññatarena gāḷhena roga ātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa na evam hoti
translated: But he would not think:

original: ‘piyā vata maṁ kāmā jahissanti, piye cāhaṁ kāme jahissāmī’ti.
analyzed: piyāḥ vata mam kāmāḥ jahissanti piye ca aham kāme jahissāmi iti
translated: ‘Oh, how dear to me are sensual pleasures, and yet they are leaving me, and I am leaving sensual pleasures!’

original: So na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṁ kandati, na sammohaṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: saḥ na socati na kilamati na paridevati na uras tāḷim kandati na sammoham āpajjati
translated: He would not grieve, be tormented, and weep; he would not beat his breast and become confused.

original: Ayaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa.
analyzed: ayam kho brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammaḥ samānaḥ na bhāyati na santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa
translated: This is the one who, though subject to death, is not frightened or terrified of death.

original: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco kāye vītarāgo hoti vigatacchando vigatapemo vigatapipāso vigatapariḷāho vigatataṇho.
analyzed: puna capara brāhmaṇaḥ idha ekaccaḥ kāye vīta rāgaḥ hoti vigata chandaḥ vigata pemaḥ vigata pipāsaḥ vigata pariḷāhaḥ vigata taṇhaḥ
translated: “Again, a certain person is free from passion, desire, fondness, thirst, fever, and craving for the body.

original: Tamenaṁ aññataro gāḷho rogātaṅko phusati.
analyzed: tam enam aññataraḥ gāḷhaḥ roga ātaṅkaḥ phusati
translated: Then a certain severe illness befalls him.

original: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa na evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa aññatarena gāḷhena roga ātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa na evam hoti
translated: But it doesn’t occur to him:

original: ‘piyo vata maṁ kāyo jahissati, piyañcāhaṁ kāyaṁ jahissāmī’ti.
analyzed: piyaḥ vata mama kāyaḥ jahissati piyam ca aham kāyam jahissāmi iti
translated: ‘Oh, may this body of mine be separated from its dear life! May I be separated from this dear body!’

original: So na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṁ kandati, na sammohaṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: saḥ na socati na kilamati na paridevati na uras tāḷim kandati na sammoham āpajjati
translated: He doesn’t grieve, isn’t tormented. He doesn’t weep, beat his breast, or fall into bewilderment.

original: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa.🔽Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco akatapāpo hoti akataluddo akatakibbiso katakalyāṇo katakusalo katabhīruttāṇo.
analyzed: ayam pi kho brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammaḥ samānaḥ na bhāyati na santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa  puna capara brāhmaṇaḥ idha ekaccaḥ akata pāpaḥ hoti akata luddaḥ akata kibbisaḥ kata kalyāṇaḥ kata kusalaḥ kata bhīruttāṇaḥ
translated: This person, though subject to death, doesn’t fear it or dread it or fall into bewilderment about it.

original: Tamenaṁ aññataro gāḷho rogātaṅko phusati.
analyzed: tam enam aññataraḥ gāḷhaḥ roga ātaṅkaḥ phusati
translated: “Again, a certain person has not done evil deeds, has not done cruel deeds, has not done sinful deeds. He has done good deeds, skillful deeds, righteous deeds.🔽Then a certain severe illness befalls him.

original: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa aññatarena gāḷhena roga ātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evam hoti
translated: But it occurs to him:

original: ‘akataṁ vata me pāpaṁ, akataṁ luddaṁ, akataṁ kibbisaṁ;
analyzed: akatam vata me pāpa akatam ludda akatam kibbisa
translated: ‘I have done no evil, I have done no wicked thing, I have done no sinful thing.

original: kataṁ kalyāṇaṁ, kataṁ kusalaṁ, kataṁ bhīruttāṇaṁ.
analyzed: katam kalyāṇa katam kusala katam bhīruttāṇa
translated: I have done what is good, I have done what is wholesome, I have done what is skillful.

original: Yāvatā, bho, akatapāpānaṁ akataluddānaṁ akatakibbisānaṁ katakalyāṇānaṁ katakusalānaṁ katabhīruttāṇānaṁ gati taṁ gatiṁ pecca gacchāmī’ti.
analyzed: yāvatā bho akata pāpānam a kata luddānam a kata kibbisānam kata kalyāṇānam kata kusalānam kata bhīruttāṇānam gati tam gatim pecca gacchāmi iti
translated: Wherever those who have done no evil, done no wicked thing, done no sinful thing, but have done what is good, done what is wholesome, done what is skillful, go, that is where I am going when I am dead.’

original: So na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṁ kandati, na sammohaṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: saḥ na socati na kilamati na paridevati na uras tāḷim kandati na sammoham āpajjati
translated: He does not grieve, is not tormented, does not weep, does not beat his breast, does not become confused.

original: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa.
analyzed: ayam pi kho brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammaḥ samānaḥ na bhāyati na santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa
translated: This is the second person who, subject to death, is not afraid or in terror of death.

original: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco akaṅkhī hoti avicikicchī niṭṭhaṅgato saddhamme.
analyzed: puna capara brāhmaṇaḥ idha ekaccaḥ a kaṅkhī hoti a vicikicchī niṭṭhaṅgataḥ saddhamme
translated: “Then there is the case where a certain person is free of doubt, free of uncertainty, with his confidence well-founded regarding the True Dhamma.

original: Tamenaṁ aññataro gāḷho rogātaṅko phusati.
analyzed: tam enam aññataraḥ gāḷhaḥ roga ātaṅkaḥ phusati
translated: Then he falls into a serious illness.

original: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa aññatarena gāḷhena roga ātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evam hoti
translated: As he is afflicted with pain, he thinks:

original: ‘akaṅkhī vatamhi avicikicchī niṭṭhaṅgato saddhamme’ti.
analyzed: a kaṅkhī vatamhi a vicikicchī niṭṭhaṅgataḥ saddhamma iti
translated: ‘I am free of doubt, free of uncertainty, with my confidence well-founded regarding the True Dhamma.’

original: So na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṁ kandati, na sammohaṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: saḥ na socati na kilamati na paridevati na uras tāḷim kandati na sammoham āpajjati
translated: He does not grieve, is not tormented, does not weep, does not beat his breast, and does not fall into confusion.

original: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṁ āpajjati maraṇassa.
analyzed: ayam pi kho brāhmaṇa maraṇa dhammaḥ samānaḥ na bhāyati na santāsam āpajjati maraṇassa
translated: This is the fourth person who, subject to death, is not afraid or in terror of death.

original: Ime kho, brāhmaṇa, cattāro maraṇadhammā samānā na bhāyanti, na santāsaṁ āpajjanti maraṇassā”ti.🔽“Abhikkantaṁ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṁ, bho gotama …pe… upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.
analyzed: ime kho brāhmaṇa cattāro maraṇa dhammā samānāḥ na bhāyanti na santāsam āpajjanti maraṇassa ati  abhikkanta bho gotama abhikkanta bho gotama pe upāsakam mam bhavam gotamaḥ dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetam saraṇam gatanti
translated: These are the four people who, subject to death, are not afraid or in terror of death.”

original: Catutthaṁ.🔽Aṅguttara Nikāya 4.185
analyzed: catuttha  aṅguttara nikāya
translated: “Magnificent, Master Gotama! Magnificent! … From today let Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone to him for refuge for life.”🔽The fourth section on those subject to death is finished.

original: 19. Brāhmaṇavagga
analyzed: brāhmaṇa vagga
translated: The Book of the Fours

original: Brāhmaṇasaccasutta
analyzed: brāhmaṇasaccasutta
translated: The Brahmins’ Four Truths

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha on the Vulture Peak Mountain.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā paribbājakā sippinikātīre paribbājakārāme
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā paribbājakā sippinikā tīre paribbājaka ārāme
translated: Now on that occasion many well-known wanderers were staying at the Wanderers’ Rest House by the Sīha hut on the Sīha Hill.

original: paṭivasanti, seyyathidaṁ annabhāro varadharo sakuludāyī ca paribbājako aññe ca abhiññātā
analyzed: paṭivasanti seyyathidam anna bhāraḥ vara dharaḥ sa kula udāyī ca paribbājakaḥ aññe ca abhiññātā
translated: were living in the Mango Grove, namely: Annabhara, Varadhara, Sakuludayin the wanderer, and other well-known wanderers,

original: abhiññātā paribbājakā.
analyzed: abhiññātā paribbājakā
translated: and other well-known wanderers.

original: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena sippinikātīre paribbājakārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā sāyanha samayam paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitaḥ yena sippinikā tīre paribbājaka ārāmaḥ tena upasaṅkami
translated: Then, when it was evening, the Buddha came out of his seclusion and went to the wanderers’ park.

original: Tena kho pana samayena tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ ayamantarā kathā udapādi:
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena tesam añña titthiyānam paribbājakānam sannisinnānam sannipatitānam ayam antarā kathā udapādi
translated: At that time, after discussing many things, the wanderers had this discussion:

original: “itipi brāhmaṇasaccāni, itipi brāhmaṇasaccānī”ti.
analyzed: itipi brāhmaṇa saccāni itipi brāhmaṇa saccāni iti
translated: “This is the brahmin’s truth, this is the brahmin’s truth.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā yena te paribbājakā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho bhagavā te paribbājake etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā yena te paribbājakā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi nisajja kho bhagavā te paribbājake etat avoca
translated: The Buddha went to them and sat down on a prepared seat. He then said to the wanderers,

original: “Kāya nuttha, paribbājakā, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
analyzed: kāya nuttha paribbājakāḥ etarahi kathāya sannisinnā kā ca pana vaḥ antarākathā vippakatā ati
translated: “Wanderers, what were you sitting talking about? What conversation was unfinished?”

original: “Idha, bho gotama, amhākaṁ sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
analyzed: idha bho gotama amhākam sannisinnānam sannipatitānam ayam antarākathā udapādi
translated: “We were sitting talking about many things, sir,

original: ‘itipi brāhmaṇasaccāni, itipi brāhmaṇasaccānī’”ti.
analyzed: itipi brāhmaṇa saccāni itipi brāhmaṇa saccāni iti
translated: ‘These are the brahmin’s truths, these are the brahmin’s truths.’

original: “Cattārimāni, paribbājakā, brāhmaṇasaccāni mayā sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
analyzed: cattāri imāni paribbājakāḥ brāhmaṇa saccāni mayā sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni
translated: “Wanderers, I have declared these four brahmin’s truths after directly knowing them myself.

original: Katamāni cattāri?
analyzed: katamāni cattāri
translated: What are the four?

original: Idha, paribbājakā, brāhmaṇo evamāha:
analyzed: idha paribbājakāḥ brāhmaṇaḥ evam āha
translated: Here, wanderers, a brahmin says this:

original: ‘sabbe pāṇā avajjhā’ti.
analyzed: sabbe pāṇāḥ avajjhāti
translated: ‘All living beings should not be killed.’

original: Iti vadaṁ brāhmaṇo saccaṁ āha, no musā.
analyzed: iti brāhmaṇaḥ saccam āha naḥ musā
translated: Saying this, the brahmin speaks the truth, not a lie.

original: So tena na samaṇoti maññati, na brāhmaṇoti maññati, na seyyohamasmīti maññati, na sadisohamasmīti maññati, na hīnohamasmīti maññati.
analyzed: saḥ tena na samaṇa iti maññati na brāhmaṇa iti maññati na seyyā uham asmi iti maññati na sadisā uham asmi iti maññati na hīnā uham asmi iti maññati
translated: He does not think, ‘I am a contemplative,’ or ‘I am a brahmin,’ or ‘I am better,’ or ‘I am equal,’ or ‘I am worse.’

original: Api ca yadeva tattha saccaṁ tadabhiññāya pāṇānaṁyeva anuddayāya anukampāya paṭipanno hoti.
analyzed: api ca yat eva tattha saccam tat abhiññāya an uddayāya anukampāya paṭipannaḥ hoti
translated: But rather, having directly known what is true there, he practices for the welfare of all living beings, out of compassion for all living beings.

original: Puna caparaṁ, paribbājakā, brāhmaṇo evamāha:
analyzed: puna capara paribbājakāḥ brāhmaṇaḥ evam āha
translated: Again, wanderers, a brahmin says this:

original: ‘sabbe kāmā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti.
analyzed: sabbe kāmā aniccāḥ dukkhāḥ vipariṇāma dhammā ti
translated: ‘All sensual desires are impermanent, suffering, and subject to change.’

original: Iti vadaṁ brāhmaṇo saccamāha, no musā.
analyzed: iti brāhmaṇaḥ saccam āha no musā
translated: Saying this, the brahmin speaks the truth, not a lie.

original: So tena na samaṇoti maññati, na brāhmaṇoti maññati, na seyyohamasmīti maññati, na sadisohamasmīti maññati, na hīnohamasmīti maññati.
analyzed: saḥ tena na samaṇa iti maññati na brāhmaṇa iti maññati na seyyā uham asmi iti maññati na sadisā uham asmi iti maññati na hīnā uham asmi iti maññati
translated: He does not think, ‘I am an ascetic,’ ‘I am a brahmin,’ ‘I am better,’ ‘I am equal,’ ‘I am worse.’

original: Api ca yadeva tattha saccaṁ tadabhiññāya kāmānaṁyeva nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
analyzed: api ca yat eva tattha saccam tat abhiññāya kāmānayā iva nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti
translated: But rather, having directly known that which is real there, he is practicing for the purpose of disenchantment, dispassion, and cessation regarding sensuality.

original: Puna caparaṁ, paribbājakā, brāhmaṇo evamāha:
analyzed: puna capara paribbājakāḥ brāhmaṇaḥ evam āha
translated: Again, wanderers, a brahmin says this:

original: ‘sabbe bhavā aniccā …pe… tadabhiññāya bhavānaṁyeva nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
analyzed: sabbe bhavāḥ aniccāḥ pe tat abhiññāya bhavānayā iva nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti
translated: ‘All kinds of existence are impermanent …’ … Having directly known that which is real there, he is practicing for the purpose of disenchantment, dispassion, and cessation regarding existence.

original: Puna caparaṁ, paribbājakā, brāhmaṇo evamāha:
analyzed: puna capara paribbājakāḥ brāhmaṇaḥ evam āha
translated: Again, wanderers, a brahmin says this:

original: ‘nāhaṁ kvacani kassaci kiñcanatasmiṁ na ca mama kvacani katthaci kiñcanatatthī’ti.
analyzed: na aham kvacani kassaci kiñcana tasmin na ca mama kvacani katthaci kiñcana tatthi iti
translated: ‘I am not anyone’s, nor does anything belong to me.’

original: Iti vadaṁ brāhmaṇo saccaṁ āha, no musā.
analyzed: iti brāhmaṇaḥ saccam āha naḥ musā
translated: When he says this, the brahmin speaks the truth, not a falsehood.

original: So tena na samaṇoti maññati, na brāhmaṇoti maññati, na seyyohamasmīti maññati, na sadisohamasmīti maññati, na hīnohamasmīti maññati.
analyzed: saḥ tena na samaṇa iti maññati na brāhmaṇa iti maññati na seyyā uham asmi iti maññati na sadisā uham asmi iti maññati na hīnā uham asmi iti maññati
translated: He does not think, ‘I am an ascetic,’ ‘I am a brahmin,’ ‘I am better,’ ‘I am equal,’ ‘I am worse.’

original: Api ca yadeva tattha saccaṁ tadabhiññāya ākiñcaññaṁyeva paṭipadaṁ paṭipanno hoti.🔽Imāni kho, paribbājakā, cattāri brāhmaṇasaccāni mayā sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditānī”ti.
analyzed: api ca yat eva tattha saccam tat abhiññāya ākiñcaññayā iva paṭipadam paṭipanno hoti  imāni kho paribbājakā cattāri brāhmaṇa saccāni mayā sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni iti
translated: But he practices the way that leads to nothingness, having directly known and realized it for himself right within.

original: Pañcamaṁ.
analyzed: pañcama
translated: These are the four noble truths of the brahmans that I have discovered, having directly known and realized them for myself.”🔽The fifth section on the brahmans is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 4.186
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Fives

original: 19. Brāhmaṇavagga
analyzed: brāhmaṇa vagga
translated: The Group on Brahmans

original: Ummaggasutta
analyzed: ummagga sutta
translated: The Peak

original: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho aññataraḥ bhikkhu yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho saḥ bhikkhu bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then a certain monk went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

original: “kena nu kho, bhante, loko nīyati, kena loko parikassati, kassa ca uppannassa vasaṁ gacchatī”ti?
analyzed: kena nu kho bhante lokaḥ nīyati kena lokaḥ parikassati kassa ca uppannassa vasam gacchati iti
translated: “Venerable sir, by what is the world led? By what is the world dragged around? Who does the world belong to when it arises, and who does it belong to when it is annihilated?”

original: “Sādhu sādhu, bhikkhu.
analyzed: sādhu sādhu bhikkhu
translated: “Good, good, monk!

original: Bhaddako kho te, bhikkhu, ummaggo, bhaddakaṁ paṭibhānaṁ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
analyzed: bhaddakaḥ kho te bhikkhu ummaggaḥ bhaddakam paṭibhāna kalyāṇī paripucchā
translated: Your approach is sound, monk, your question is well-phrased.

original: Evañhi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, pucchasi:
analyzed: evañhi tva bhikkhu pucchasi
translated: For you have asked thus:

original: ‘kena nu kho, bhante, loko nīyati, kena loko parikassati, kassa ca uppannassa vasaṁ gacchatī’”ti?
analyzed: kena nu kho bhante lokaḥ nīyati kena lokaḥ parikassati kassa ca uppannassa vasam gacchati iti
translated: “What is it that leads the world? What is it that the world revolves around? What is it that, when it arises, arises, and when it ceases, ceases?”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”.
analyzed: eva bhante
translated: “Yes, Bhante.”

original: “Cittena kho, bhikkhu, loko nīyati, cittena parikassati, cittassa uppannassa vasaṁ gacchatī”ti.
analyzed: cittena kho bhikkhu lokaḥ nīyati cittena parikassati cittassa uppannassa vasam gacchati iti
translated: “The mind, bhikkhu, is what leads the world. The mind is what the world revolves around. The mind is what, when it arises, arises, and when it ceases, ceases.”

original: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ uttari pañhaṁ apucchi:
analyzed: sādhu bhanta iti kho saḥ bhikkhu bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantam uttari pañham apucchi
translated: “Good, Bhante.” The bhikkhu delighted and rejoiced in the Blessed One’s words. Then he asked the Blessed One a further question:

original: “‘bahussuto dhammadharo, bahussuto dhammadharo’ti, bhante, vuccati.

translated: “‘One who is learned and remembers what he has learned,’ it is said.

original: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bahussuto dhammadharo hotī”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho bhante bahussutaḥ dhamma dharaḥ hoti iti
translated: In what way is one who is learned and remembers what he has learned?”

original: “Sādhu sādhu, bhikkhu.
analyzed: sādhu sādhu bhikkhu
translated: “Good, good, bhikkhu!

original: Bhaddako kho te, bhikkhu ummaggo, bhaddakaṁ paṭibhānaṁ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
analyzed: bhaddakaḥ kho te bhikkhu ummaggaḥ bhaddakam paṭibhāna kalyāṇī paripucchā

original: ‘bahussuto dhammadharo, bahussuto dhammadharoti, bhante, vuccati.

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”.

original: “Bahū kho, bhikkhu, mayā dhammā desitā—
analyzed: bahū kho bhikkhu mayā dhammā desitā
translated: “Bhikkhu, I have taught many teachings:

original: suttaṁ, geyyaṁ, veyyākaraṇaṁ, gāthā, udānaṁ, itivuttakaṁ, jātakaṁ, abbhutadhammaṁ, vedallaṁ.
analyzed: sutta geyya veyyākaraṇa gāthā udāna itivuttaka jātaka abbhutadhamma vedalla
translated: discourses, mixed prose and verse, expositions, verses, inspired utterances, quotations, birth stories, amazing accounts, and questions-and-answers.

original: Catuppadāya cepi, bhikkhu, gāthāya atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya dhammānudhammappaṭipanno hoti bahussuto dhammadharoti alaṁvacanāyā”ti.
analyzed: catuppadāya ce pi bhikkhu gāthāya attha maññāya dhamma maññāya dhamma anudhamma ppaṭipannaḥ hoti bahu ssutaḥ dhammadharo ti alavacanāya ati
translated: If one understands the meaning and the Dhamma of even a four-line verse, one is called learned and a master of the teachings.”

original: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ uttari pañhaṁ apucchi:

original: “‘sutavā nibbedhikapañño, sutavā nibbedhikapañño’ti, bhante, vuccati.

translated: “‘One who is learned and has penetrating wisdom, one who is learned and has penetrating wisdom,’ it is said.

original: “Sādhu sādhu, bhikkhu.

translated: “Good, good, bhikkhu!

original: Bhaddako kho te, bhikkhu, ummaggo, bhaddakaṁ paṭibhānaṁ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
analyzed: bhaddakaḥ kho te bhikkhu ummaggaḥ bhaddakam paṭibhāna kalyāṇī paripucchā
translated: Your approach and your question are excellent, bhikkhu.

original: Evañhi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, pucchasi:
analyzed: evañhi tva bhikkhu pucchasi

original: ‘sutavā nibbedhikapañño, sutavā nibbedhikapaññoti, bhante, vuccati.
analyzed: sutavā nibbedhika pañño sutavā nibbedhika pañño ti bhante vuccati

analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho bhante sutavā nibbedhika paññaḥ hoti iti

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”.
analyzed: eva bhante
translated: “Yes, lord.”

original: “Idha, bhikkhu, bhikkhuno ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti sutaṁ hoti, paññāya cassa atthaṁ ativijjha passati;🔽‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti sutaṁ hoti, paññāya cassa atthaṁ ativijjha passati;🔽‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti sutaṁ hoti, paññāya cassa atthaṁ ativijjha passati;
analyzed: idha bhikkhu bhikkhuno idam dukkhan ti sutam hoti paññāya ca ssa attham ativijjha passati  ayam dukkha samudayaḥ ti sutam hoti paññāya ca ssa attham ativijjha passati  ayam dukkha nirodho ti sutam hoti paññāya ca ssa attham ativijjha passati
translated: “It’s when a monk has heard: ‘This is suffering.’ He sees that meaning with wisdom.🔽He has heard: ‘This is the origination of suffering.’ He sees that meaning with wisdom.🔽He has heard: ‘This is the cessation of suffering.’ He sees that meaning with wisdom.

analyzed: evam kho bhikkhu sutavā nibbedhika paññaḥ hoti iti

translated: “Yes, lord.”

original: “Idha, bhikkhu, paṇḍito mahāpañño nevattabyābādhāya ceteti na parabyābādhāya ceteti na ubhayabyābādhāya ceteti attahitaparahitaubhayahitasabbalokahitameva cintayamāno cinteti.

translated: “Once, when a gathering of brahmins was criticizing others in the presence of the brahmin Todeyya,

original: ‘bālo ayaṁ rājā eḷeyyo samaṇe rāmaputte abhippasanno, samaṇe ca pana rāmaputte evarūpaṁ paramanipaccakāraṁ karoti, yadidaṁ abhivādanaṁ paccuṭṭhānaṁ añjalikammaṁ sāmīcikammanti.

translated: he said, ‘This King Eḷeyya is a fool, devoted to the Sakyan monastics. He has the utmost confidence in them, and so he bows down to them, stands up for them, raises his joined palms to them, and does acts of respect toward them.

original: Imepi rañño eḷeyyassa parihārakā bālā—

original: samaṇe ca pana rāmaputte evarūpaṁ paramanipaccakāraṁ karonti, yadidaṁ abhivādanaṁ

translated: They have the utmost confidence in them, and so they bow down to them, stand up for them, raise their joined palms to them, and do acts of respect toward them.’

original: paccuṭṭhānaṁ añjalikammaṁ sāmīcikamman’ti.
analyzed: paccuṭṭhānam añjali kammam sāmīci kammanti

original: Tyāssudaṁ todeyyo brāhmaṇo iminā nayena neti.

translated: And Todeyya the brahmin went along with this.

original: ‘Taṁ kiṁ maññanti, bhonto,

translated: ‘What do you think, sirs?

translated: Is King Eḷeyya wise, and is he more wise than those who are wise, and more skilled than those who are skilled?’

translated: ‘Yes, sir, King Eḷeyya is wise, and he is more wise than those who are wise, and more skilled than those who are skilled.’

analyzed: yasmā ca kho bho samaṇaḥ rāma putto raññā eḷeyyena paṇḍitena paṇḍitataraḥ karaṇīya adhikaraṇīyesu  vacanīya adhivacanīyesu alamattha dasatarena alamattha dasataro tasmai rājā eḷeyyaḥ samaṇe
translated: ‘But sirs, because the ascetic Rāmaputta is wiser than King Eḷeyya,🔽and more skilled than those who are skilled, that is why King Eḷeyya has such confidence in the ascetic Rāmaputta,

analyzed: rāmaputte abhippasanno samaṇe ca pana rāmaputte evarūpam parama nipacca kāram karoti

original: vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.

analyzed: upekkhā sahagatena cetasā ekam disam pharitvā viharati tathā dutiyam tathā tatiya  tathā catutthaḥ iti uddham adhas tiriyam sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantam lokam upekkhā sahagatena

analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ ti ākāsānañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati  sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati  sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: Here, a bhikkhu, with the complete surmounting of perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of sensory impact, with non-attention to perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite,’ enters and dwells in the base of the infinity of space.🔽With the complete surmounting of the base of the infinity of space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite,’ he enters and dwells in the base of the infinity of consciousness.🔽With the complete surmounting of the base of the infinity of consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing,’ he enters and dwells in the base of nothingness.

original: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanam samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the complete surmounting of the base of nothingness, he enters and dwells in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āneñjappatto hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu āneñja ppattaḥ hoti

translated: There is the case where a monk discerns, as it actually is, that ‘This is stress… This is the origination of stress… This is the cessation of stress… This is the way leading to the cessation of stress.

analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu ariya ppattaḥ hoti iti

translated: the discourses, mixed prose and verse, expositions, verses, inspired utterances, quotations, birth stories, amazing accounts, and questions-and-answers.

translated: He learns those teachings by ear and memorizes them, recites them, and examines them with the mind, and ponders them with the mind.

original: So muṭṭhassati kālaṁ kurumāno aññataraṁ devanikāyaṁ upapajjati.

original: Tassa tattha na heva kho sukhino dhammapadā plavanti, napi bhikkhu iddhimā cetovasippatto devaparisāyaṁ dhammaṁ deseti;

original: api ca kho devaputto devaparisāyaṁ dhammaṁ deseti.
analyzed: api ca kho deva puttaḥ deva parisāyam dhammaṃ deseti

original: Tassa evaṁ hoti:

original: Dandho, bhikkhave, satuppādo;

original: atha so satto khippaṁyeva visesagāmī hoti.

translated: but that being will soon make progress.

original: Sotānugatānaṁ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṁ, vacasā paricitānaṁ, manasānupekkhitānaṁ, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhānaṁ ayaṁ tatiyo ānisaṁso pāṭikaṅkho.
analyzed: sotā anugatāna bhikkhave dhammāna vacasā paricitāna manasā an upekkhitāna diṭṭhiyā su paṭividdhānam ayam tatiyaḥ ānisasaḥ pāṭikaṅkho

translated: He learns them well, memorizes them, and masters them verbally. He examines the meaning with his wisdom and recognizes it with wisdom.

original: So muṭṭhassati kālaṁ kurumāno aññataraṁ devanikāyaṁ upapajjati.

original: So evamāha:

original: ‘Saṁvāsena, bhikkhave, sīlaṁ veditabbaṁ, tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṁ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti,

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco ñātibyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno, bhogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno, rogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno na iti paṭisañcikkhati:

translated: “There is the case where one touched by loss of relatives, loss of property, or loss through disease does not reflect:🔽‘Such is property, such is its arising, such is its disappearance.

original: ‘tathābhūto kho ayaṁ lokasannivāso tathābhūto ayaṁ attabhāvapaṭilābho yathābhūte
analyzed: tathābhūtaḥ kho ayam loka sannivāso tathābhūtaḥ ayam atta bhāva paṭilābhaḥ yathābhūte
translated: Such is the gratification in property, such is the danger, such the escape.

original: lokasannivāse yathābhūte attabhāvapaṭilābhe aṭṭha lokadhammā lokaṁ anuparivattanti
analyzed: loka sannivāse yathābhūte atta bhāva paṭilābhe aṭṭha loka dhammāḥ lokam anuparivattanti
translated: The eight worldly conditions revolve around the world,

original: loko ca aṭṭha lokadhamme anuparivattati—
analyzed: loko ca aṭṭha loka dhamme anuparivattati
translated: and the world revolves around the eight worldly conditions:

original: lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṁsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañcā’ti.
analyzed: lābho ca alābho ca yaso ca ayaso ca nindā ca pasasā ca sukham ca dukkham ca ati
translated: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.

original: So ñātibyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno bhogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno rogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṁ kandati, sammohaṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: saḥ ñāti byasanena vā phuṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ bhoga byasanena vā phuṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ roga byasanena vā phuṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ socati kilamati paridevati uras tāḷim kandati sammoham āpajjati
translated: When touched by a misfortune concerning relatives, wealth, or illness, he grieves, sorrows, and laments; he weeps beating his breast and becomes confused.

original: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco ñātibyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno bhogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno rogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno iti paṭisañcikkhati:🔽‘tathābhūto kho ayaṁ lokasannivāso tathābhūto ayaṁ attabhāvapaṭilābho yathābhūte
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhave ekaccaḥ ñāti byasanena vā phuṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ bhoga byasanena vā phuṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ roga byasanena vā phuṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati  tathābhūtaḥ kho ayam loka sannivāso tathābhūtaḥ ayam atta bhāva paṭilābhaḥ yathābhūte
translated: But when touched by a misfortune concerning relatives, wealth, or illness, he considers this:🔽‘This is how it is when one has a rebirth with the eight worldly conditions.🔽The eight worldly conditions revolve around the world,

original: lokasannivāse yathābhūte attabhāvapaṭilābhe aṭṭha lokadhammā lokaṁ anuparivattanti
analyzed: loka sannivāse yathābhūte atta bhāva paṭilābhe aṭṭha loka dhammāḥ lokam anuparivattanti
translated: and the world revolves around the eight worldly conditions:🔽gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.’

original: loko ca aṭṭha lokadhamme anuparivattati—
analyzed: loko ca aṭṭha loka dhamme anuparivattati
translated: The world revolves around the eight worldly conditions:

original: lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṁsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañcā’ti.
analyzed: lābho ca alābho ca yaso ca ayaso ca nindā ca pasasā ca sukham ca dukkham ca ati
translated: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.

original: So ñātibyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno bhogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno rogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṁ kandati, na sammohaṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: saḥ ñāti byasanena vā phuṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ bhoga byasanena vā phuṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ roga byasanena vā phuṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ na socati na kilamati na paridevati na uras tāḷim kandati na sammoham āpajjati
translated: When a person is affected by misfortune regarding relatives, wealth, or sickness, they don’t sorrow, grieve, and lament; they don’t weep beating their breast and become confused.

original: ‘Āpadāsu, bhikkhave, thāmo veditabbo, so ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṁ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti,
analyzed: āpadāsu bhikkhave thāmaḥ veditabbo so ca kho dīghena addhunā na ittara manasikarotā no a manasikarotā paññavatā no duppaññena ati
translated: ‘Their fortitude should be known in times of adversity, and that takes a long time, not just a short time; it requires attention, not lack of attention; and it requires wisdom, not a lack of wisdom.’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vuttam idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: That’s why I said this.

original: ‘Sākacchāya, bhikkhave, paññā veditabbā, sā ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṁ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti,
analyzed: bhikkhave paññā veditabbā sā ca kho dīghena addhunā na manasikarotā no a manasikarotā paññavatā no duppaññena ati
translated: ‘Their wisdom should be known in discussion, and that takes a long time, not just a short time; it requires attention, not lack of attention; and it requires wisdom, not a lack of wisdom.’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

original: Idha, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalena saddhiṁ sākacchāyamāno evaṁ jānāti:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave puggalaḥ puggalena saddhim sākacchāyamānaḥ evam jānāti
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, when conversing with someone, one comes to know:

original: ‘yathā kho imassa āyasmato ummaggo yathā ca abhinīhāro yathā ca pañhāsamudāhāro, duppañño ayamāyasmā, nāyamāyasmā paññavā.
analyzed: yathā kho imassa āyasmataḥ ummaggaḥ yathā ca abhinīhāraḥ yathā ca pañhā samudāhāraḥ duppaññaḥ ayam āyasmā na ayam āyasmā paññavā
translated: ‘Judging from the way this venerable speaks to me, he is not wise, he is not an adept in what pertains to the discipline of the noble ones.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Tathā hi ayamāyasmā na ceva gambhīraṁ atthapadaṁ udāharati santaṁ paṇītaṁ atakkāvacaraṁ nipuṇaṁ paṇḍitavedanīyaṁ.🔽Yañca ayamāyasmā dhammaṁ bhāsati tassa ca nappaṭibalo saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā atthaṁ ācikkhituṁ desetuṁ paññāpetuṁ paṭṭhapetuṁ vivarituṁ vibhajituṁ uttānīkātuṁ.
analyzed: tathā hi na ca iva gambhīram attha padam udāharati santam paṇītam a takka avacaram nipuṇam paṇḍita vedanīya  yat ca ayam āyasmai dhammam bhāsati tassa ca na paṭibalaḥ saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā attham ācikkhitum desetum paññāpetum paṭṭhapetum vivaritum vibhajitum uttānīkātu
translated: Because this venerable does not expound the teachings that are beautiful in the beginning, beautiful in the middle, and beautiful in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and which proclaim the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life.🔽And he is not able to explain the Dhamma in such a way that one of keen faculties, on hearing it, might come to the conclusion: “This is the Dhamma; this is the discipline; this is the Teacher’s instruction.”

original: Duppañño ayamāyasmā, nāyamāyasmā paññavā’ti.
analyzed: duppaññaḥ ayam āyasmā na ayam āyasmā paññavāti
translated: Judging from the way this venerable speaks to me, he is not wise, he is not an adept in what pertains to the discipline of the noble ones.’

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, cakkhumā puriso udakarahadassa tīre ṭhito passeyya parittaṁ macchaṁ ummujjamānaṁ.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave cakkhumā purisaḥ udaka rahadassa tīre ṭhitaḥ passeyya parittam maccham ummujjamāna
translated: “Suppose a man with good sight, standing on the bank of a pond, were to see a small fish emerging,

original: Tassa evamassa:
analyzed: tassa evamassa
translated: and he thought:

original: ‘yathā kho imassa macchassa ummaggo yathā ca ūmighāto yathā ca vegāyitattaṁ, paritto ayaṁ maccho, nāyaṁ maccho mahanto’ti.
analyzed: yathā kho imassa macchassa ummaggaḥ yathā ca ūmighātaḥ yathā ca vegāyitatta parittaḥ ayam macchaḥ na ayam macchaḥ mahantaḥ iti
translated: ‘From the way this fish rises to the surface, the way it swims about and dives down, it’s a small fish, not a big one.’

original: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalena saddhiṁ sākacchāyamāno evaṁ jānāti:
analyzed: evam evam kho bhikkhave puggalaḥ puggalena saddhim sākacchāyamānaḥ evam jānāti
translated: In the same way, when a person is conversing with another, he understands this:

original: ‘yathā kho imassa āyasmato ummaggo yathā ca abhinīhāro yathā ca pañhāsamudāhāro, duppañño ayamāyasmā, nāyamāyasmā paññavā.
analyzed: yathā kho imassa āyasmataḥ ummaggaḥ yathā ca abhinīhāraḥ yathā ca pañhā samudāhāraḥ duppaññaḥ ayam āyasmā na ayam āyasmā paññavā
translated: ‘From the way this venerable one raises the discussion, the way he expresses himself, and the way he asks his questions, he’s not discerning enough to know whether a person is accomplished or whether he is not.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?🔽Tathā hi ayamāyasmā na ceva gambhīraṁ atthapadaṁ udāharati santaṁ paṇītaṁ atakkāvacaraṁ nipuṇaṁ paṇḍitavedanīyaṁ.
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu  tathā hi na ca iva gambhīram attha padam udāharati santam paṇītam a takka avacaram nipuṇam paṇḍita vedanīya
translated: Why is that?🔽Because this venerable one doesn’t expound the teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and reveal a holy life that’s utterly perfect and pure.

original: Yañca ayamāyasmā dhammaṁ bhāsati, tassa ca na paṭibalo saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā atthaṁ ācikkhituṁ desetuṁ paññāpetuṁ paṭṭhapetuṁ vivarituṁ vibhajituṁ uttānīkātuṁ.
analyzed: yat ca ayam āyasmai dhammam bhāsati tassa ca na paṭibalaḥ saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā attham ācikkhitum desetum paññāpetum paṭṭhapetum vivaritum vibhajitum uttānīkātu
translated: And he’s not able to explain, teach, describe, establish, reveal, expound, and exhibit the teachings that the Buddha has taught in detail and in brief.

original: Duppañño ayamāyasmā, nāyamāyasmā paññavā’ti.
analyzed: duppaññaḥ ayam āyasmā na ayam āyasmā paññavāti
translated: He’s not discerning enough to know whether a person is accomplished or whether he is not.’

original: Idha pana, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalena saddhiṁ sākacchāyamāno evaṁ jānāti:
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhave puggalaḥ puggalena saddhim sākacchāyamānaḥ evam jānāti
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, when conversing with someone, one comes to know:

original: ‘yathā kho imassa āyasmato ummaggo yathā ca abhinīhāro yathā ca pañhāsamudāhāro, paññavā ayamāyasmā, nāyamāyasmā duppañño.
analyzed: yathā kho imassa āyasmataḥ ummaggaḥ yathā ca abhinīhāraḥ yathā ca pañhā samudāhāraḥ paññavā ayam āyasmā na ayam āyasmā duppaññaḥ
translated: ‘Judging from the way this venerable speaks about the path of practice leading to cessation, he is wise, not unwise.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?🔽Tathā hi ayamāyasmā gambhīrañceva atthapadaṁ udāharati santaṁ paṇītaṁ atakkāvacaraṁ nipuṇaṁ paṇḍitavedanīyaṁ.

translated: Why is that?🔽Because this venerable speaks about a deep matter, one that is hard to see and hard to understand, subtle, to be experienced by the wise, and he does not misrepresent the Teacher or the Dhamma.

original: Yañca ayamāyasmā dhammaṁ bhāsati, tassa ca paṭibalo saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā atthaṁ ācikkhituṁ desetuṁ paññāpetuṁ paṭṭhapetuṁ vivarituṁ vibhajituṁ uttānīkātuṁ.
analyzed: yat ca ayam āyasmai dhammam bhāsati tassa ca paṭibalaḥ saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā attham ācikkhitum desetum paññāpetum paṭṭhapetum vivaritum vibhajitum uttānīkātu
translated: And he is able to explain, teach, describe, establish, reveal, expound, and exhibit the Dhamma.

original: Paññavā ayamāyasmā, nāyamāyasmā duppañño’ti.
analyzed: paññavā ayam āyasmā na ayam āyasmā duppañño ti
translated: He is wise, not unwise.’

analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave cakkhumā purisaḥ udaka rahadassa tīre ṭhitaḥ passeyya mahantam maccham ummujjamāna
translated: “Suppose a man with good sight, standing on the bank of a pond, were to see a large fish emerging,

analyzed: paññavā ayam āyasmā na ayam āyasmā duppañño ti

original: ‘Sākacchāya, bhikkhave, paññā veditabbā, sā ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṁ; manasikarotā,
analyzed: bhikkhave paññā veditabbā sā ca kho dīghena addhunā na ittara manasikarotā
translated: “Monks, wisdom can be known through discussion, but that takes time, not a short period.

original: 20. Mahāvagga

analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā vesāliyam viharati mahā vane kūṭāgāra sālāya
translated: One time the Blessed One was living at Vesālī in the Great Wood in the hall with the peaked roof.🔽Then Bhaddiya the Licchavi went to the Blessed One, and after paying homage to him, he sat down at one side

translated: and said to the Blessed One:

original: “Sutaṁ metaṁ, bhante:

original: Ye te, bhante, evamāhaṁsu:
analyzed: ye te bhante
translated: “Venerable sir, those who say this:

original: ‘māyāvī samaṇo gotamo āvaṭṭaniṁ māyaṁ jānāti yāya aññatitthiyānaṁ sāvake āvaṭṭetī’ti,
analyzed: māyāvī samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ āvaṭṭanim mā ayam jānāti yāya añña titthiyānam sāvake āvaṭṭeti iti
translated: ‘The ascetic Gotama is a magician, and he has the magic trick of making others disappear.’

original: kacci te, bhante, bhagavato vuttavādino, na ca bhagavantaṁ abhūtena abbhācikkhanti,
analyzed: kacci te bhante bhagavataḥ vutta vādinaḥ na ca bhagavantam abhūtena abbhācikkhanti

analyzed: dhammassa ca anudhammam byākaronti na ca koci sahadhammikaḥ vāda anupātaḥ
translated: Do you not misrepresent the Blessed Lord’s Teaching, and will those who speak thus be speaking in accordance with the Dhamma?

original: āgacchati, anabbhakkhātukāmā hi mayaṁ, bhante, bhagavantan”ti?🔽“Etha tumhe, bhaddiya, mā anussavena, mā paramparāya, mā itikirāya, mā piṭakasampadānena,
analyzed: āgacchati an abbhakkhātu kāmāḥ hi bhante bhagavantanti  tumhe bhaddiya mā anussavena mā paramparāya mā itikirāya mā piṭaka sampadānena
translated: For we do not want to misrepresent the Blessed Lord.”

original: mā takkahetu, mā nayahetu, mā ākāraparivitakkena, mā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā, mā
analyzed: mā takka hetu mā naya hetu mā ākāra parivitakkena mā diṭṭhi nijjhāna khantiyā mā
translated: “Come, Bhaddiya, do not go by oral tradition, by lineage of teaching, by hearsay, by a collection of texts, by logic, by inferential reasoning, by reasoned cogitation, by the acceptance of a view after pondering it, by the seeming competence of a speaker,

original: bhabbarūpatāya, mā ‘samaṇo no garū’ti.
