original: So na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na eḷakamantaraṁ na
analyzed: saḥ na kumbhi mukhā paṭiggaṇhāti na kaḷopi mukhā paṭiggaṇhāti na eḷakam antaram na
translated: He does not receive food with his own hand from door to door, but only from a house where he is invited to take a meal.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even from a house where he is invited to take a meal, but only from the courtyard.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even from the courtyard, but only from the threshold.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even from the threshold, but only from the doorstep.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even from the doorstep, but only from the edge of the doorstep.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even from the edge of the doorstep, but only from the edge of the almsbowl.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even from the edge of the almsbowl, but only when the food is held level with the tip of the nose.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even when the food is held level with the tip of the nose, but only when the food is held lower than the tip of the nose.

original: daṇḍamantaraṁ na musalamantaraṁ na dvinnaṁ bhuñjamānānaṁ na gabbhiniyā na pāyamānāya🔽na purisantaragatāya na saṅkittīsu na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti na yattha makkhikā🔽saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī na macchaṁ na maṁsaṁ na suraṁ na merayaṁ na thusodakaṁ pivati.
analyzed: daṇḍam antaram na musalam antaram na dvinnam bhuñjamānānam na gabbhiniyā na pāyamānāya  na purisa antara gatāya na saṅkittīsu na yattha sā upaṭṭhitaḥ hoti na yattha makkhikā  saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī na maccham na masam na suram na merayam na thusa udakam pivati
translated: He does not receive food with his own hand even when the food is held lower than the tip of the nose, but only when the food is held out at arm’s length.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even when the food is held out at arm’s length, but only when the food is held out beyond arm’s length.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even when the food is held out beyond arm’s length, but only when the food is held out level with the shoulder.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even when the food is held out level with the shoulder, but only when the food is held out above the shoulder.

original: So ekāgāriko vā hoti ekālopiko dvāgāriko vā hoti dvālopiko …pe… sattāgāriko vā hoti sattālopiko;
analyzed: so ekāgārikaḥ vā hoti ekālopikaḥ dvāgārikaḥ vā hoti dvālopikaḥ pe satta āgārikaḥ vā hoti satta ālopikaḥ
translated: He does not receive food with his own hand even when the food is held out above the shoulder, but only when the food is held out level with the head.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even when the food is held out level with the head, but only when the food is held out above the head.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even when the food is held out above the head, but only when the food is held out level with the forehead.🔽He does not receive food with his own hand even when the food is held out level with the forehead, but only when the food is held out level with the nose.

original: ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti …pe… sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti;🔽ekāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti dvāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti …pe… sattāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti. Iti evarūpaṁ aḍḍhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
analyzed: ekissā api dattiyā yāpeti dvīhi pi dattīhi yāpeti pe sattahi pi dattīhi yāpeti 🔽ekāhikam pi āhāram āhāreti dvāhikam pi āhāram āhāreti pe sattāhikam pi āhāram āhāreti iti evarūpam aḍḍhamāsikam pi pariyāya bhatta bhojana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ viharati
translated: He does not receive food

original: So sākabhakkhopi hoti sāmākabhakkhopi hoti nīvārabhakkhopi hoti daddulabhakkhopi🔽hoti haṭabhakkhopi hoti kaṇabhakkhopi hoti ācāmabhakkhopi hoti piññākabhakkhopi hoti
analyzed: so sāka bhakkhaḥ api hoti sāmāka bhakkhaḥ api hoti nīvāra bhakkhaḥ api hoti daddula bhakkhaḥ api  hoti haṭa bhakkhaḥ api hoti kaṇa bhakkhaḥ api hoti ācāma bhakkhaḥ api hoti piññāka bhakkhaḥ api hoti
translated: He eats rice that is picked out from the husks. He eats millet. He eats wild rice. He eats reed seeds. He eats water lily roots. He eats rice bran. He eats rice scum. He eats grass. He eats leaves.

original: tiṇabhakkhopi hoti gomayabhakkhopi hoti; vanamūlaphalāhāropi yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.🔽So sāṇānipi dhāreti masāṇānipi dhāreti chavadussānipi dhāreti paṁsukūlānipi dhāreti🔽tirīṭānipi dhāreti ajinampi dhāreti ajinakkhipampi dhāreti kusacīrampi dhāreti vākacīrampi🔽dhāreti phalakacīrampi dhāreti kesakambalampi dhāreti vāḷakambalampi dhāreti ulūkapakkhampi dhāreti;
analyzed: tiṇa bhakkhaḥ api hoti gomaya bhakkhaḥ api hoti vana mūla phala āhāraḥ api yāpeti pavatta phala bhojī  saḥ sāṇāni api dhārā iti masāṇāni api dhārā iti chava dussāni api dhārā iti pasu kūlāni api dhārā iti  tirīṭāni api dhārā iti ajinampi dhārā iti ajinakkhipampi dhārā iti kusa cīrampi dhārā iti vāka cīrampi  dhāreti phalaka cīram pi dhāreti kesa kambalam pi dhāreti vāḷa kambalam pi dhāreti ulūka pakkham pi dhāreti
translated: He eats rice, or meat, or fish, or porridge, or mung-bean soup, or sesame flour, or curd, or milk, or ghee, or molasses, or he lives on forest roots and fruits, eating grass like an ox, going where it grows.🔽He wears robes of strips of wood-apple bark, or robes of strips of silk-cotton tree bark, or robes of strips of kīta bark, or robes of strips of antelope hide, or robes of strips of lion’s hide, or robes of strips of tiger’s hide, or robes of strips of leopard’s hide, or robes of strips of human skin, or robes of strips of snake skin, or robes of owls’ wings.

original: kesamassulocakopi hoti kesamassulocanānuyogamanuyutto;🔽ubbhaṭṭhakopi hoti āsanappaṭikkhitto;
analyzed: kesa massu locakaḥ api hoti kesa massu locana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ  ubbhaṭṭhakaḥ api hoti āsana paṭikkhittaḥ
translated: He shaves off all the hair on his body, or he shaves off all the hair on his body and then scratches it off, or he shaves off all the hair on his body and then scratches it off and rubs it in with his hand.🔽He stands continuously, rejecting seats,

original: ukkuṭikopi hoti ukkuṭikappadhānamanuyutto;
analyzed: ukkuṭikaḥ api hoti ukkuṭika padhānam anuyuttaḥ
translated: or he squats continuously, not lying down even when sick,

original: kaṇṭakāpassayikopi hoti kaṇṭakāpassaye seyyaṁ kappeti;🔽sāyatatiyakampi udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
analyzed: kaṇṭakāpassayikaḥ api hoti kaṇṭakāpassaye seyyam kappeti  udakorohana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ viharati
translated: He lies down on a bed of thorns, or he makes his bed and seat of thorns.🔽He practices submerging in water three times a day, even at the cost of his life.

original: Iti evarūpaṁ anekavihitaṁ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
analyzed: iti evarūpam aneka vihitam kāyassa ātāpana paritāpana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ viharati
translated: Thus he lives devoted to the practice of torturing and tormenting himself.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo attantapo hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave puggalaḥ attantapaḥ hoti atta paritāpana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ
translated: This is how one torments oneself and is devoted to the practice of torturing oneself.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo parantapo hoti paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave puggalaḥ parantapaḥ hoti para paritāpana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ
translated: “And how does one torment others and is devoted to the practice of torturing others?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo orabbhiko hoti sūkariko sākuṇiko māgaviko luddo macchaghātako coro coraghātako goghātako bandhanāgāriko, ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ orabbhikaḥ hoti sūkarikaḥ sākuṇikaḥ māgavikaḥ luddaḥ maccha ghātako coraḥ cora ghātako go ghātako bandhanāgārikaḥ ye vā pana aññe pi keci kurūra kammantā
translated: Here someone is a butcher of sheep, a butcher of pigs, a butcher of fowl, a trapper, a hunter, a fisherman, a thief, an executioner, a prison warden, or one who follows any other bloody occupation.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo parantapo hoti paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave puggalaḥ parantapaḥ hoti para paritāpana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ
translated: This is how one torments others and is devoted to the practice of torturing others.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo attantapo ca hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave puggalaḥ attantapaḥ ca hoti atta paritāpana anuyoga manuyuttaḥ parantapaḥ ca para paritāpana anuyoga manuyuttaḥ
translated: “And how is a person one who torments himself and pursues the practice of torturing himself and who torments others and pursues the practice of torturing others?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo rājā vā hoti khattiyo muddhāvasitto, brāhmaṇo vā hoti mahāsālo.🔽So puratthimena nagarassa navaṁ santhāgāraṁ kārāpetvā kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kharājinaṁ
analyzed: idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ rājā vā hoti khattiyaḥ muddhāvasittaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ vā hoti mahā sālaḥ  saḥ puratthimena nagarassa navam santhāgāram kārāpetvā kesa massum ohāretvā
translated: There is the case where a person is a head-anointed noble warrior king.🔽He has a new gabled reception hall built, has his hair & beard trimmed, puts on new clothes, new sandals, and new ornaments, and smears his body with oil.

original: nivāsetvā sappitelena kāyaṁ abbhañjitvā magavisāṇena piṭṭhiṁ kaṇḍuvamāno navaṁ santhāgāraṁ🔽pavisati, saddhiṁ mahesiyā brāhmaṇena ca purohitena.
analyzed: nivāsetvā sappi telena kāyam abbhañjitvā maga visāṇena piṭṭhim kaṇḍuvamānaḥ navam  pavisati saddhim mahesiyā brāhmaṇena ca purohitena
translated: Then he enters the new gabled reception hall, accompanied by the chief consort or a court lady, and scratches it with his nails.

original: So tattha anantarahitāya bhūmiyā haritupalittāya seyyaṁ kappeti.🔽Ekissāya gāviyā sarūpavacchāya yaṁ ekasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti tena rājā yāpeti; yaṁ
analyzed: saḥ tattha anantara hitāya bhūmiyā harita upalittāya seyyam kappeti  ekissāya gāviyā sarūpavacchāya yam ekasmin thane khīram hoti tena rājā yāpeti ya
translated: He lies down on the bare ground strewn with grass.

original: dutiyasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti tena mahesī yāpeti; yaṁ tatiyasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti
analyzed: dutiyasmin thane khīram hoti tena mahesī yā apeti yam tatiyasmin thane khīram hoti
translated: From one cow he takes milk; from another, curds; from another, butter; from another, ghee; and from another, cream-of-ghee.

original: tena brāhmaṇo purohito yāpeti; yaṁ catutthasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti tena aggiṁ juhati;
analyzed: tena brāhmaṇaḥ purohitaḥ yāpa iti yam catutthasmin thane khīram hoti tena aggim juhati
translated: The brahmin priest lives on the milk of the second cow,

original: avasesena vacchako yāpeti.
analyzed: avasesena vacchakaḥ yāpa iti
translated: and the calf lives on what is left.

original: So evamāha:
analyzed: sā u evam āha
translated: He says:🔽‘So many bulls are to be killed for the sacrifice, so many bullocks …

original: ‘ettakā usabhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatarā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā🔽vacchatariyo haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā ajā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā urabbhā
analyzed: ettakāḥ usabhāḥ haññantu yaññatthāya ettakāḥ vacchatarāḥ haññantu yaññatthāya ettakā  vacchatariyaḥ haññantu yaññatthāya ettakāḥ ajāḥ haññantu yaññatthāya ettakāḥ urabbhā
translated: so many heifers … so many goats … so many sheep …

original: haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā assā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā rukkhā chijjantu yūpatthāya,
analyzed: haññantu yañña tthāya ettakāḥ assāḥ haññantu yañña tthāya ettakāḥ rukkhāḥ chijjantu yūpa tthāya
translated: so many horses … so many trees are to be cut down for the sacrificial posts …

original: ettakā dabbhā lūyantu barihisatthāyā’ti.
analyzed: ettakāḥ dabbhāḥ lūyantu barihi satthāya ati
translated: so much grass is to be cut for the sacrificial grass.’

original: Yepissa te honti dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā tepi daṇḍatajjitā bhayatajjitā assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni karonti.
analyzed: ye pi issa te honti dāsā ati vā pessā ati vā kammakarā ati vā te pi daṇḍa tajjitāḥ bhaya tajjitāḥ assu mukhāḥ rudamānā parikammāni karonti
translated: And those who are his slaves, servants, and workers do their work with weeping faces, being beaten, abused, and threatened by him, their bodies covered with sweat.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo attantapo ca hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave puggalaḥ attantapaḥ ca hoti atta paritāpana anuyoga manuyuttaḥ parantapaḥ ca para paritāpana anuyoga manuyuttaḥ
translated: This is how one torments oneself and torments others, and on account of tormenting himself and others, after death, at the breaking-up of the body, he is reborn in an unhappy destination, in a bad destination, in a lower world, in hell.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo nevattantapo hoti nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?🔽So anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave puggalaḥ na iva attantapaḥ hoti na ātta paritāpana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ na parantapaḥ na para paritāpana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ  so anattantapaḥ aparantapaḥ diṭṭhe iva dhamme nicchātaḥ nibbutaḥ sītībhūto sukha ppaṭisavedī brahma bhūtena attanā viharati
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, is one a person who torments himself and pursues the practice of torturing himself and who torments others and pursues the practice of torturing others?🔽“Here, bhikkhus, someone generates afflictive bodily activity, generates afflictive verbal activity, generates afflictive mental activity, and he encourages others to generate afflictive bodily activity, to generate afflictive verbal activity, and to generate afflictive mental activity.🔽“Thus he is one who torments himself and pursues the practice of torturing himself and who torments others and pursues the practice of torturing others.

original: Idha, bhikkhave, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.🔽So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave tathāgataḥ loke uppajjati araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampannaḥ sugataḥ loka vidū anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathi satthā deva manussānam buddhaḥ bhagavā  saḥ imam lokam sa devakam sa mārakam sa brahmakam sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇim pajam sa deva manussam sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, a Tathagata appears in the world, accomplished, fully enlightened …🔽He reveals this world—with its devas, Mara, and Brahma, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its devas and hum ans—having himself realized it through direct knowledge.

original: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
analyzed: saḥ dhammam deseti ādi kalyāṇam majjhe kalyāṇam pariyosāna kalyāṇam sa attham sa byañjana kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddham brahmacariyam pakāseti
translated: He teaches the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and he reveals a holy life that is utterly perfect and pure.

original: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.🔽So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
analyzed: tam dhammam suṇāti gahapati vā gahapati putto vā aññatarasmim vā kule paccājātaḥ  saḥ tam dhammam sutvā tathāgate saddham paṭilabhati
translated: He hears the Dhamma of the kind already mentioned.🔽Having heard the Dhamma, he acquires faith in the Tathāgata.

original: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: saḥ tena saddhā paṭilābhena samannāgataḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: Endowed with this faith, he considers thus:

original: ‘sambādho gharāvāso rajāpatho, abbhokāso pabbajjā;
analyzed: sambādhaḥ gharāvāsaḥ rajāpathaḥ abbhokāsaḥ pabbajjā
translated: ‘Household life is crowded and dusty; life gone forth is wide open.

original: nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ;
analyzed: na idam sukaram agāram ajjhāvasatā ekanta paripuṇṇam ekanta parisuddham saṅkha likhitam brahmacariyam caritu
translated: It is not easy, while living in a home, to lead the holy life utterly perfect and pure as a polished shell.

original: yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.🔽So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya, mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya,
analyzed: yat nūna aham kesa massuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajeyyanti  so aparena samayena appam vā bhogakkhandham pahāya mahantam vā bhogakkhandham pahāya
translated: Suppose I shave off my hair and beard, put on the yellow robe, and go forth from the home life into homelessness.’

original: appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya, mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya, kesamassuṁ ohāretvā
analyzed: appam vā ñāti parivaṭṭam pahāya mahantam vā ñāti parivaṭṭam pahāya kesa massuṃ ohāretvā
translated: “Then, after some time, he abandons a small or large fortune, abandons a small or large circle of relatives, and—having shaved off his hair and beard, put on the yellow robe, and gone forth from the home life into homelessness—🔽 Translation: He hears the Dhamma of such a kind as a clansman can, on hearing it, come to accept the true Dhamma.🔽Having heard the Dhamma, he acquires faith in the Tathāgata.🔽Endowed with this faith, he considers thus:🔽‘Household life is crowded and dusty; life gone forth is wide open.🔽It is not easy, while living in a home, to lead the holy life utterly perfect and pure as a polished shell.

original: kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
analyzed: kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajati
translated: Suppose I shave off my hair and beard, put on the yellow robe, and go forth from the home life into homelessness.’🔽“Then, after some time, he abandons a small or large fortune, abandons a small or large circle of relatives, and—having shaved off his hair and beard, put on the yellow robe, and gone forth from the home life into homelessness—

original: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno bhikkhūnaṁ sikkhāsājīvasamāpanno pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā🔽paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
analyzed: so evam pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ bhikkhūnam sikkhā sājīva samāpannaḥ pāṇātipātam pahāya pāṇātipātā  paṭivirataḥ hoti nihita daṇḍaḥ nihita satthaḥ lajjī dayā āpanno sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī viharati
translated: Having gone forth thus, he becomes endowed with the bhikkhus’ training and way of life. He abstains from killing living beings, from taking what is not given,🔽from misconduct in sensual pleasures, from false speech, and from wine, liquor, and intoxicants, which are the basis of negligence.🔽He abstains from eating at night, from accepting gold and silver.🔽He abstains from accepting raw grain,

original: Adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
analyzed: a dinna ādānam pahāya a dinna ādānā paṭivirataḥ hoti dinna ādāyī dinna pāṭikaṅkhī atha enena sucibhūtena attanā viharati
translated: from accepting raw meat,🔽from accepting women and girls,🔽from accepting men and women slaves,

original: Abrahmacariyaṁ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato asaddhammā gāmadhammā.🔽Musāvādaṁ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṁvādako lokassa.
analyzed: a brahmacariyam pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārā cārī virataḥ asat dhammā gāma dhammā  musāvādam pahāya musāvādā paṭivirataḥ hoti sacca vādī sacca sandho theto paccayikaḥ a visavādakaḥ lokassa
translated: from accepting goats and sheep,🔽from accepting fowl and pigs,🔽from accepting elephants, cattle, horses, and mares,🔽from accepting fields and land.🔽He abstains from going on errands, from buying and selling,🔽from cheating with false weights and measures,🔽from accepting deposits,

original: Pisuṇaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, na ito sutvā amutra akkhātā
analyzed: pisuṇam vācam pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirataḥ hoti na itas sutvā amutra
translated: from bribery, deception, and fraud,🔽from mutilating living beings, from inflicting wounds with a knife,🔽and from appropriating the property of others by force or stealth.

original: imesaṁ bhedāya, na amutra vā sutvā imesaṁ akkhātā amūsaṁ bhedāya; iti bhinnānaṁ vā
analyzed: imesam bhedāya na amutra vā sutvā imesam akkhātā amūsam bhedāya iti bhinnānam vā
translated: He abstains from accepting a wife and taking on a son,

original: sandhātā, sahitānaṁ vā anuppadātā, samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.🔽Pharusaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
analyzed: sandhātā sahitānam vai anuppadātā samagga ārāmaḥ samagga rataḥ samagga nandī samagga karaṇim vācam bhāsitā hoti  pharusam vācam pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirataḥ hoti yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇa sukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahu jana kantā bahu jana manāpā tathārūpim vācam bhāsitā hoti
translated: He is a reconciler of those at variance and a reuniter of the divided. He loves concord, delights in concord, is fond of concord, speaks things that create concord.🔽He has abandoned false speech and abstains from false speech. He speaks the truth and holds to the truth, is firm in the truth, reliable, no deceiver of the world.🔽He has abandoned malicious speech and abstains from malicious speech. He does not repeat elsewhere what he has heard here in order to divide those people from these, nor does he repeat to these people what he has heard elsewhere in order to divide these people from those; thus he is one who reunites those who are at variance and promotes friendships, delights in concord, rejoices in concord, loves concord, speaks things that create concord.

original: Samphappalāpaṁ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī
analyzed: samphappalāpam pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirataḥ hoti kāla vādī bhūta vādī attha vādī
translated: He has abandoned harsh speech and abstains from harsh speech. He speaks words that are gentle, pleasing to the ear, endearing, going to the heart, urbane, amiable, and agreeable to many people.

original: dhammavādī vinayavādī; nidhānavatiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti kālena sāpadesaṁ pariyantavatiṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ.
analyzed: dhamma vādī vinaya vādī nidhānavatim vācam bhāsitā hoti kālena sa apadesam pariyantavatim attha sahita
translated: He has abandoned gossip and abstains from gossip. He speaks in season, speaks what is factual, what is in accordance with the goal, the Dhamma, and the Vinaya. He speaks words worth treasuring, seasonable, reasonable, circumscribed, and endowed with meaning.

original: So bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato hoti.
analyzed: saḥ bīja gāma bhūta gāma samārambhā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: He abstains from injuring seeds and plants.

original: Ekabhattiko hoti rattūparato virato vikālabhojanā.🔽Naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā paṭivirato hoti.
analyzed: eka bhattikaḥ hoti rattu uparataḥ virataḥ vikāla bhojanā  nacca gīta vādita visūka dassanā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: He eats only in one part of the day, refraining from food at night and from eating at improper times.🔽He abstains from dancing, singing, instrumental music, and witnessing unsuitable shows.

original: Mālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti.
analyzed: mālā gandha vilepana dhāraṇa maṇḍana vibhūsana ṭṭhānā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: He abstains from wearing garlands, embellishing himself with scents, and beautifying himself with unguents.

original: Uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato hoti.🔽Jātarūparajatapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.
analyzed: uccāsayana mahāsayanā paṭivirataḥ hoti  jātarūpa rajata paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: He abstains from high and luxurious beds and seats.🔽He abstains from accepting gold and silver.

original: Āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.🔽Āmakamaṁsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.🔽Itthikumārikapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.🔽Dāsidāsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.
analyzed: āmaka dhañña paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirataḥ hoti  āmaka masa paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirataḥ hoti  itthi kumārika paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirataḥ hoti  dāsi dāsa paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: He abstains from accepting raw grain.🔽He abstains from accepting raw meat.🔽He abstains from accepting women and girls.

original: Ajeḷakapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.🔽Kukkuṭasūkarapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.🔽Hatthigavāssavaḷavapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.
analyzed: ajeḷaka paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirataḥ hoti  kukkuṭa sūkara paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirataḥ hoti  hatthi gavāssa vaḷava paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: He abstains from accepting male and female slaves.🔽He abstains from accepting goats and sheep.🔽He abstains from accepting fowl and pigs.

original: Khettavatthupaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.🔽Dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato hoti.
analyzed: khetta vatthu paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirataḥ hoti  dūteyya pahiṇa gamana anuyogā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: He abstains from accepting elephants, cattle, horses, and mares.🔽He abstains from running messages.

original: Kayavikkayā paṭivirato hoti.🔽Tulākūṭakaṁsakūṭamānakūṭā paṭivirato hoti.🔽Ukkoṭanavañcananikatisāciyogā paṭivirato hoti.
analyzed: kaya vikkayā paṭivirataḥ hoti  tulā kūṭaka sa kūṭa māna kūṭā paṭivirataḥ hoti  ukkoṭana vañcana nikati sāci yogā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: He abstains from buying and selling.🔽He abstains from cheating with false weights and measures.🔽He abstains from cheating by using tricks and ruses.

original: Chedanavadhabandhanaviparāmosaālopasahasākārā paṭivirato hoti.
analyzed: chedana vadha bandhana viparāmosa ālopa sahasākārā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: He abstains from cheating by manipulating goods.🔽He abstains from taking what is not given.

original: So santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
analyzed: saḥ santuṭṭhaḥ hoti kāya parihārikena cīvarena kucchi parihārikena piṇḍapātena so yena yena iva pakkamati samādāya iva pakkamati
translated: He is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever he goes, he sets out taking only these things.

original: Seyyathāpi nāma pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti, sapattabhārova ḍeti;
analyzed: seyyathā api nāma pakkhī sakuṇaḥ yena yena iva ḍeti sa patta bhāraḥ uva ḍeti
translated: Just as a bird, wherever it goes, flies with its wings as its only burden,

original: evamevaṁ bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati.
analyzed: evam evam bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ hoti kāya parihārikena cīvarena kucchi parihārikena piṇḍapātena saḥ yena yena iva pakkamati samādāya iva pakkamati
translated: so too is the bhikkhu content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever he goes, he sets out taking only these things.

original: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ anavajjasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: saḥ iminā ariyena sīla kkhandhena samannāgataḥ ajjhattam anavajja sukham paṭisavedeti
translated: Endowed with this aggregate of noble virtue, he experiences within himself a bliss that is blameless.

original: So cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.🔽Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: so cakkhunā rūpam disvā na nimitta ggāhī hoti na anubyañjana ggāhī  yatvā adhikaraṇam enam cakkhu indriyam asavutam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: On seeing a form with the eye, he does not grasp at its signs and features.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati; rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ; cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjati rakkhati cakkhu indriya cakkhu indriye savaram āpajjati
translated: Since, if he left the eye faculty unguarded, evil unwholesome states of covetousness and grief might invade him, he practises the way of its restraint, he guards the eye faculty, he undertakes the restraint of the eye faculty.

original: Sotena saddaṁ sutvā …
analyzed: sotena saddam sutvā
translated: On hearing a sound with the ear…

original: ghānena gandhaṁ ghāyitvā …🔽jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …
analyzed: ghānena gandham ghāyitvā  jivhāya rasam sāyitvā
translated: Having smelt an odour with the nose …🔽Having tasted a flavour with the tongue …

original: kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusitvā …
analyzed: kāyena phoṭṭhabbam phusitvā
translated: Having felt an object with the body …

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya na nimitta ggāhī hoti na anubyañjana ggāhī
translated: Having cognized a mind-object with the mind, he does not grasp at its general appearance or its details.

original: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: yatvā adhikaraṇam enam man indriyam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: If he were to live without restraint over the mind faculty, evil unwholesome states of longing and dejection might invade him.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati; rakkhati manindriyaṁ; manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjati rakkhati manindriya manindriye savaram āpajjati
translated: So he practices for the restraining of the mind faculty; he guards the mind faculty, he achieves restraint over the mind faculty.

original: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ abyāsekasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.🔽So abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti,🔽samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti,
analyzed: saḥ iminā ariyena indriya savarena samannāgataḥ ajjhattam a byāseka sukham paṭisaveda iti  saḥ abhikkante paṭikkante sampajāna kārī hoti ālokite vilokite sampajāna kārī hoti  samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti
translated: Endowed with this noble restraint of the faculties, he experiences within himself a bliss that is blameless.🔽He is one who acts with awareness when going forward and returning;🔽who acts with awareness when looking ahead and looking away;🔽who acts with awareness when flexing and extending his limbs; who acts with awareness when wearing his robes and carrying his outer robe and bowl;

original: asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti,
analyzed: asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajāna kārī hoti uccāra passāva kamme sampajāna kārī hoti
translated: who acts with awareness when eating, drinking, consuming food, and tasting; who acts with awareness when defecating and urinating;

original: gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
analyzed: gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajāna kārī hoti
translated: in going forwards & backwards, he is one who practises with full awareness.

original: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato,
analyzed: so iminā ca ariyena sīla kkhandhena samannāgataḥ imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgataḥ
translated: “Endowed with this aggregate of noble virtue, endowed with this noble sort of contentment,

original: iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato
analyzed: iminā ca ariyena indriya savarena samannāgataḥ iminā ca ariyena sati sampajaññena samannāgataḥ
translated: endowed with this noble restraint of the faculties, endowed with this noble mindfulness & alertness,

original: vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanappatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
analyzed: vivittam senāsanam bhajati araññam rukkha mūlam pabbatam kandaram giri guham su sānam vanappattham abbhokāsam palāla puñja
translated: he resorts to a secluded dwelling: a forest, the shade of a tree, a mountain, a ravine, a hillside cave, a charnel ground, a jungle grove, the open air, a heap of straw.

original: So pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.🔽So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: saḥ pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā  saḥ abhijjham loke pahāya vigata abhijjhena cetasā viharati abhijjhāya cittam parisodheti
translated: After his meal, returning from his alms round, he sits down, crosses his legs, holds his body erect, and brings mindfulness to the fore.🔽Abandoning worldly thoughts, he dwells with his mind well established in the four frames of reference.

original: Byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: byāpāda padosam pahāya a byāpanna cittaḥ viharati sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī byāpāda padosā cittam parisodheti
translated: Abandoning worldly thoughts, he dwells with his mind well established in the four frames of reference.

original: Thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: thinamiddham pahāya vigata thinamiddhaḥ viharati āloka saññī sataḥ sampajānaḥ thinamiddhā cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up stiffness and torpor, gets rid of restlessness and remorse, and so enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without thinking or investigation, with inner clarity and mental unification, without thinking or investigation.🔽He purifies his mind from stiffness and torpor.

original: Uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti.🔽Vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: uddhacca kukkuccam pahāya anuddhataḥ viharati ajjhattam vūpasanta cittaḥ uddhacca kukkuccā cittam parisodheti  vicikiccham pahāya tiṇṇa vicikicchaḥ viharati a kathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu vicikicchāya cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up doubt, gets rid of uncertainty, and so enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without thinking or investigation, with inner clarity and mental unification, without thinking or investigation.🔽He purifies his mind from doubt.

original: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
analyzed: saḥ ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetasaḥ upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
translated: He abandons these five hindrances, corruptions of the mind and weakeners of wisdom,

original: vivicceva kāmehi …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: vivicca iva kāmehi pe catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: and so, detached from sense pleasures, detached from unwholesome states, he enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of detachment, and focuses on the absence of thinking and pondering.🔽With his mind thus concentrated, purified, and bright, unblemished, free from defects, pliant, malleable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines it to knowledge of the recollection of past lives.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya …pe…
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇāya pe
translated: He recollects his manifold past lives, with features and details.

original: sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya …pe…
analyzed: sattānam cutūpapāta ñāṇāya pe
translated: He directs and inclines it to knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.🔽He understands how beings pass away and reappear according to their actions.

original: āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāma iti
translated: He directs and inclines it to knowledge of the destruction of the corruptions.

original: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: saḥ idam dukkhan ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering’;

original: ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti🔽yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodho ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati  yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: he understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’

original: ‘Ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,🔽‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti
analyzed: ime āsavāḥ ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti  ayam āsava nirodha uti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘These are the taints’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of the taints’;

original: yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: he understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the taints’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’

original: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati;
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati bhava āsavā api cittam vimuccati avijjā āsavā api cittam vimuccati
translated: When he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being, and from the taint of ignorance.

original: vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
analyzed: vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: When it is liberated there comes the knowledge: ‘It is liberated.’

original: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo nevattantapo hoti nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave puggalaḥ na ivattantapaḥ hoti na ātta paritāpana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ na parantapaḥ na para paritāpana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ
translated: This is how a person is neither tormented nor a tormentor of himself, nor tormented or a tormentor of others.

original: So na attantapo na parantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.
analyzed: so na attantapaḥ na parantapaḥ diṭṭhā iva dhamme nicchātaḥ nibbutaḥ sītībhūtaḥ sukha paṭisavedī brahma bhūtena attanā viharati
translated: He is neither tormented nor a tormentor, and he dwells in the here-and-now free of hunger, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, dwelling in pure happiness, having become a Brahma.

original: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puggalā santo saṁvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
analyzed: ime kho bhikkhave cattāro puggalā santaḥ sa vijjamānāḥ lokasmin ti
translated: These are the four kinds of persons to be found existing in the world.”🔽The eighth section on the person who is complete in faculties is finished.

original: Aṭṭhamaṁ.🔽Aṅguttara Nikāya 4.199
analyzed: aṭṭhama  aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Tens

original: 20. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Greater Section

original: Taṇhāsutta
analyzed: taṇhā sutta
translated: Craving

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:🔽“taṇhaṁ vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi jāliniṁ saritaṁ visaṭaṁ visattikaṁ, yāya ayaṁ loko
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca  taṇham vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi jālinim saritam ayam lokaḥ
translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: uddhasto pariyonaddho tantākulakajāto gulāguṇṭhikajāto muñjapabbajabhūto apāyaṁ duggatiṁ
analyzed: uddhastaḥ pariyonaddhaḥ tantā kulaka jātaḥ gulā guṇṭhika jātaḥ muñja pabbaja bhūtaḥ apāyam duggati
translated: “Bhikkhus, I will teach you craving—a net, a jungle, a thicket, a writhing, constricting, binding, and delusive thing, through which this world has been conquered, overcome, and obstructed, so that it cannot cross over the great wilderness, the great wildwood, the great expanse.

original: vinipātaṁ saṁsāraṁ nātivattati.
analyzed: vinipātam sa sāram na ativattati
translated: Through which this world has been conquered, overcome, and obstructed, so that it cannot cross over the great wilderness, the great wildwood, the great expanse, and go beyond to suffering’s end.

original: Taṁ suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tam suṇātha sādhukam manasi karotha bhāsissāmi iti
translated: Listen and attend closely to what I shall say.”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: eva bhante iti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato
translated: “Yes, Bhante,” those bhikkhus replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:🔽“Katamā ca sā, bhikkhave, taṇhā jālinī saritā visaṭā visattikā, yāya ayaṁ loko uddhasto
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca  katamā ca sā bhikkhave taṇhā jālinī saritā visaṭā visattikā yāya ayam lokaḥ uddhastaḥ
translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: pariyonaddho tantākulakajāto gulāguṇṭhikajāto muñjapabbajabhūto apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ🔽saṁsāraṁ nātivattati?
analyzed: pariyonaddhaḥ tantā kulaka jātaḥ gulā guṇṭhika jātaḥ muñja pabbaja bhūtaḥ apāyam duggatim vinipāta  sa sāram na ativattati
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is that craving — accompanied by passion and delight, resulting in attachment — due to which this world has become a tangle, a thicket, a dense growth, a nexus of meshwork, a process, a source, an (active) root, a destination, a lower realm, an (active) root of suffering?

original: Aṭṭhārasa kho panimāni, bhikkhave, taṇhāvicaritāni ajjhattikassa upādāya, aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritāni bāhirassa upādāya.
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa kho panimāni bhikkhave taṇhā vicaritāni ajjhattikassa upādāya aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni bāhirassa upādāya
translated: There are, bhikkhus, eighteen kinds of craving-conduit, based on the internal, and eighteen kinds of craving-conduit, based on the external.

original: Katamāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritāni ajjhattikassa upādāya?🔽Asmīti, bhikkhave, sati itthasmīti hoti, evaṁsmīti hoti, aññathāsmīti hoti, asasmīti🔽hoti, satasmīti hoti, santi hoti, itthaṁ santi hoti, evaṁ santi hoti, aññathā santi
analyzed: katamāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni ajjhattikassa upādāya  asmi iti bhikkhave sati itthasmi iti hoti evasmi iti hoti aññathā asmi iti hoti asasmi iti  hoti satasmi iti hoti santi hoti ittham santi hoti evam santi hoti aññathā santi
translated: What are the eighteen kinds of craving-conduit, based on the internal?

original: hoti, apihaṁ santi hoti, apihaṁ itthaṁ santi hoti, apihaṁ evaṁ santi hoti, apihaṁ
analyzed: hoti apiham santi hoti apiham ittham santi hoti apiham evam santi hoti apiha
translated: When there is ‘I am’ there is ‘I am thus’, there is ‘I am such’, there is ‘I am otherwise’, there is ‘I am possessed of’, there is ‘I am not’, there is ‘I am possessed of thus’, there is ‘I am possessed of such’, there is ‘I am possessed of otherwise’, there is ‘I am possessed of this’, there is ‘I am possessed of that’, there is ‘I am possessed of otherwise’, there is ‘I am not possessed of this’, there is ‘I am not possessed of that’, there is ‘I am not possessed of otherwise’.

original: aññathā santi hoti, bhavissanti hoti, itthaṁ bhavissanti hoti, evaṁ bhavissanti hoti,
analyzed: aññathā santi hoti bhavissanti hoti ittham bhavissanti hoti evam bhavissanti hoti
translated: ‘It was’, ‘It will be’, ‘It will be thus’, ‘It will be like this’,

original: aññathā bhavissanti hoti.
analyzed: aññathā bhavissanti hoti
translated: ‘It will be otherwise,’ ‘It will be both thus and otherwise,’ ‘It will be neither thus nor otherwise.’

original: Imāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritāni ajjhattikassa upādāya.
analyzed: imāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni ajjhattikassa upādāya
translated: “These are the eighteen stations of craving based on the internal.

original: Katamāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritāni bāhirassa upādāya?
analyzed: katamāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni bāhirassa upādāya
translated: “What are the eighteen stations of craving based on the external?

original: Imināsmīti, bhikkhave, sati iminā itthasmīti hoti, iminā evaṁsmīti hoti, iminā aññathāsmīti🔽hoti, iminā asasmīti hoti, iminā satasmīti hoti, iminā santi hoti, iminā itthaṁ santi
analyzed: iminā asmi iti bhikkhave sati iminā itthasmi iti hoti iminā evasmi iti hoti iminā aññathā asmi iti  hoti iminā asasmi iti hoti iminā satasmi iti hoti iminā santi hoti iminā ittham santi
translated: “With ‘I am this’ there is ‘I am this’ and ‘I am thus,’ ‘I am otherwise,’🔽‘I am not,’ ‘I am empty,’ ‘It is,’ ‘It is thus,’ ‘It is otherwise,’

original: hoti, iminā evaṁ santi hoti, iminā aññathā santi hoti, iminā apihaṁ santi hoti, iminā
analyzed: hoti iminā evam santi hoti iminā aññathā santi hoti iminā apiham santi hoti iminā
translated: ‘It is not,’ ‘It is empty,’ ‘It will be,’ ‘It will be thus,’ ‘It will be otherwise,’🔽‘It will be neither thus nor otherwise.’

original: apihaṁ itthaṁ santi hoti, iminā apihaṁ evaṁ santi hoti, iminā apihaṁ aññathā santi
analyzed: apiham ittham santi hoti iminā apiham evam santi hoti iminā apiham aññathā santi
translated: “With ‘I am this’ there is ‘I am this’ and ‘I am thus,’ ‘I am otherwise,’🔽‘I am not,’ ‘I am empty,’ ‘It is,’ ‘It is thus,’ ‘It is otherwise,’

original: hoti, iminā bhavissanti hoti, iminā itthaṁ bhavissanti hoti, iminā evaṁ bhavissanti
analyzed: hoti iminā bhavissanti hoti iminā ittham bhavissanti hoti iminā evam bhavissanti
translated: ‘It is not,’ ‘It is empty,’ ‘It will be,’ ‘It will be thus,’ ‘It will be otherwise,’

original: hoti, iminā aññathā bhavissanti hoti.
analyzed: hoti iminā aññathā bhavissanti hoti
translated: ‘It will be neither thus nor otherwise.’

original: Imāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritāni bāhirassa upādāya.
analyzed: imāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni bāhirassa upādāya
translated: These are the eighteen kinds of mental fermentation based on what is external.

original: Iti aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritāni ajjhattikassa upādāya, aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritāni bāhirassa upādāya.
analyzed: iti aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni ajjhattikassa upādāya aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni bāhirassa upādāya
translated: Thus there are eighteen kinds of mental fermentation based on what is internal, and eighteen kinds of mental fermentation based on what is external.

original: Imāni vuccanti, bhikkhave, chattiṁsa taṇhāvicaritāni.
analyzed: imāni vuccanti bhikkhave chattisa taṇhā vicaritāni
translated: These are called the thirty-six kinds of mental fermentation.

original: Iti evarūpāni atītāni chattiṁsa taṇhāvicaritāni, anāgatāni chattiṁsa taṇhāvicaritāni, paccuppannāni chattiṁsa taṇhāvicaritāni.
analyzed: iti evarūpāni atītāni chattisa taṇhā vicaritāni anāgatāni chattisa taṇhā vicaritāni paccuppannāni chattisa taṇhā vicaritāni
translated: Thus there are thirty-six kinds of mental fermentation in the past, thirty-six kinds of mental fermentation in the future, and thirty-six kinds of mental fermentation in the present.

original: Evaṁ aṭṭhasataṁ taṇhāvicaritaṁ honti.
analyzed: evam aṭṭhasatam taṇhā vicaritam honti
translated: Thus there are one hundred and eight kinds of mental fermentation.

original: Ayaṁ kho sā, bhikkhave, taṇhā jālinī saritā visaṭā visattikā, yāya ayaṁ loko uddhasto🔽pariyonaddho tantākulakajāto guṇāguṇṭhikajāto muñjapabbajabhūto apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ
analyzed: ayam kho sā bhikkhave taṇhā jālinī saritā visaṭā visattikā yāya ayam lokaḥ uddhastaḥ  pariyonaddhaḥ tantā kulaka jātaḥ guṇāguṇṭhika jātaḥ muñja pabbaja bhūtaḥ apāyam duggatim vinipāta
translated: This is that craving—agitated, worldly, causing suffering and future birth—🔽by which this world, agitated and deluded, having become entangled in craving, does not transcend

original: saṁsāraṁ nātivattatī”ti.🔽Navamaṁ.
analyzed: sa sāram na ativattati iti  navama
translated: the realm of birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and anguish.”🔽The ninth chapter on the exposition of the sixty-two views is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 4.200
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Tens

original: 20. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Greater Section

original: Pemasutta
analyzed: pemasutta
translated: Love

original: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, pemāni jāyanti.
analyzed: cattāri imāni bhikkhave pa imāni jāyanti
translated: “Monks, these four kinds of love arise.

original: Katamāni cattāri?
analyzed: katamāni cattāri
translated: What four?

original: Pemā pemaṁ jāyati,
analyzed: pemā pemam jāyati
translated: Love arises from love,

original: pemā doso jāyati,🔽dosā pemaṁ jāyati,
analyzed: dosaḥ jāyati  dosā pa imam jāyati
translated: From love, hatred arises.🔽From hatred, love arises.

original: dosā doso jāyati.
analyzed: dosā dosaḥ jāyati
translated: From hatred, hatred arises.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, pemā pemaṁ jāyati?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave pemā pemam jāyati
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, does love arise from love?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalassa iṭṭho hoti kanto manāpo.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave puggalaḥ puggalassa iṭṭhaḥ hoti kantaḥ manāpaḥ
translated: Here, bhikkhus, one person is dear and agreeable to another.

original: Taṁ pare iṭṭhena kantena manāpena samudācaranti.
analyzed: tam pare iṭṭhena kantena manāpena samudācaranti
translated: And the other person conducts himself towards the first person in a way that is dear and agreeable.

original: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa evam hoti
translated: The first person thinks:

original: ‘yo kho myāyaṁ puggalo iṭṭho kanto manāpo, taṁ pare iṭṭhena kantena manāpena samudācarantī’ti.
analyzed: yaḥ kho myā ayam puggalaḥ iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ tam pare iṭṭhena kantena manāpena samudācaranti iti
translated: ‘This person is dear and agreeable to me, and I conduct myself towards him in a way that is dear and agreeable.

original: So tesu pemaṁ janeti.
analyzed: saḥ tesu pa imam janeti
translated: ’ He generates love towards him.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pemā pemaṁ jāyati.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave pemā pemam jāyati
translated: That is how love arises from love.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, pemā doso jāyati?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave pemā dosaḥ jāyati
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, does hatred arise from love?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalassa iṭṭho hoti kanto manāpo.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave puggalaḥ puggalassa iṭṭhaḥ hoti kantaḥ manāpaḥ
translated: Here, bhikkhus, one person is dear and agreeable to another.

original: Taṁ pare aniṭṭhena akantena amanāpena samudācaranti.
analyzed: tam pare aniṭṭhena a kantena a manāpena samudācaranti
translated: And the other person conducts himself towards the first person in a way that is not dear and agreeable.

original: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa evam hoti
translated: The first person thinks:

original: ‘yo kho myāyaṁ puggalo iṭṭho kanto manāpo, taṁ pare aniṭṭhena akantena amanāpena samudācarantī’ti.
analyzed: yaḥ kho myā ayam puggalaḥ iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ tam pare an iṭṭhena a kantena a manāpena samudācaranti iti
translated: ‘This person is dear and agreeable to me, and the other person conducts himself towards him in a way that is not dear and agreeable.

original: So tesu dosaṁ janeti.
analyzed: saḥ tesu dosam janeti
translated: ’ He generates hatred towards him.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pemā doso jāyati.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave pemā dosaḥ jāyati
translated: That’s how hostility arises from affection.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dosā pemaṁ jāyati?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave dosā pemam jāyati
translated: “And how does affection arise from hostility?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalassa aniṭṭho hoti akanto amanāpo.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave puggalaḥ puggalassa aniṭṭhaḥ hoti a kantaḥ a manāpaḥ
translated: It’s when one person is disliked, objectionable, and disagreeable to another.

original: Taṁ pare aniṭṭhena akantena amanāpena samudācaranti.
analyzed: tam pare aniṭṭhena a kantena a manāpena samudācaranti
translated: And the other person treats them in a way that’s disliked, objectionable, and disagreeable.

original: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa evam hoti
translated: They think:

original: ‘yo kho myāyaṁ puggalo aniṭṭho akanto amanāpo, taṁ pare aniṭṭhena akantena amanāpena samudācarantī’ti.
analyzed: yaḥ kho myā ayam puggalaḥ aniṭṭhaḥ a kantaḥ a manāpaḥ tam pare aniṭṭhena a kantena a manāpena samudācaranti iti
translated: ‘This person is disliked, objectionable, and disagreeable to me, and the other person treats them in a way that’s disliked, objectionable, and disagreeable.’

original: So tesu pemaṁ janeti.
analyzed: saḥ tesu pa imam janeti
translated: They feel affection for the other person.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, dosā pemaṁ jāyati.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave dosā pa imam jāyati
translated: That’s how affection arises from hostility.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dosā doso jāyati?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave dosā dosaḥ jāyati
translated: “And how does hostility arise from hostility?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalassa aniṭṭho hoti akanto amanāpo.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave puggalaḥ puggalassa aniṭṭhaḥ hoti a kantaḥ a manāpaḥ
translated: It’s when one person is disliked, objectionable, and disagreeable to another.

original: Taṁ pare iṭṭhena kantena manāpena samudācaranti.
analyzed: tam pare iṭṭhena kantena manāpena samudācaranti
translated: And the other person treats them in a way that’s liked, agreeable, and pleasing.

original: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa evam hoti
translated: They think:

original: ‘yo kho myāyaṁ puggalo aniṭṭho akanto amanāpo, taṁ pare iṭṭhena kantena manāpena samudācarantī’ti.
analyzed: yaḥ kho myā ayam puggalaḥ an iṭṭhaḥ a kantaḥ a manāpaḥ tam pare iṭṭhena kantena manāpena samudācaranti iti
translated: ‘This person is disliked, objectionable, and disagreeable to me, and the other person treats them in a way that’s liked, agreeable, and pleasing.’

original: So tesu dosaṁ janeti.
analyzed: saḥ tesu dosam janeti
translated: They feel hostility toward the other person.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, dosā doso jāyati.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave dosā dosaḥ jāyati
translated: That’s how anger arises from anger.

original: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri pemāni jāyanti.
analyzed: imāni kho bhikkhave cattāri pa imāni jāyanti
translated: “These are the four kinds of love that arise.

original: Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati,
analyzed: yasmi bhikkhave samaye bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi pe paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “When a monk, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, enters & remains in the first jhāna—a happiness & bliss born of seclusion—🔽at that time there is no love for him that arises from love,

original: yampissa pemā pemaṁ jāyati tampissa tasmiṁ samaye na hoti, yopissa pemā doso jāyati🔽sopissa tasmiṁ samaye na hoti, yampissa dosā pemaṁ jāyati tampissa tasmiṁ samaye
analyzed: yam pissa pemā pemam jāyati tam pissa tasmin samaye na hoti yaḥ pissa pemā dosaḥ jāyati  saḥ upissa tasmin samaye na hoti yam pissa dosā pemam jāyati tam pissa tasmin samaye
translated: no anger for him that arises from anger,

original: na hoti, yopissa dosā doso jāyati sopissa tasmiṁ samaye na hoti.
analyzed: na hoti yaḥ upissa dosā dosaḥ jāyati saḥ upissa tasmin samaye na hoti
translated: no love for him that arises from anger, no anger for him that arises from love.

original: Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati,
analyzed: yasmin bhikkhave samaye bhikkhu vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānam pe tatiyam jhānam pe catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “When a monk, with the stilling of directed thoughts & evaluations, enters & remains in the second jhāna—which is without directed thought, without evaluation, born of concentration, filled with pleasure—🔽at that time there is no love for him that arises from love,

original: yampissa pemā pemaṁ jāyati tampissa tasmiṁ samaye na hoti, yopissa pemā doso jāyati
analyzed: yam pissa pemā pemam jāyati tam pissa tasmin samaye na hoti yaḥ pissa pemā dosaḥ jāyati
translated: no anger for him that arises from anger,

original: sopissa tasmiṁ samaye na hoti, yampissa dosā pemaṁ jāyati tampissa tasmiṁ samaye
analyzed: saḥ upissa tasmin samaye na hoti yam pissa dosā pemam jāyati tam pissa tasmin samaye
translated: and the affection that arose in him because of his lust did not exist,

original: na hoti, yopissa dosā doso jāyati sopissa tasmiṁ samaye na hoti.🔽Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ
analyzed: na hoti yaḥ upissa dosā dosaḥ jāyati saḥ upissa tasmin samaye na hoti  yasmi bhikkhave samaye bhikkhu āsavānam khayā anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimutti
translated: and the aversion that arose in him because of his aversion did not exist.🔽“Bhikkhus, on whatever occasion a bhikkhu, with the destruction of the taints, enters and dwells in the taintless liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom,

original: diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati, yampissa pemā pemaṁ🔽jāyati tampissa pahīnaṁ hoti ucchinnamūlaṁ tālāvatthukataṁ anabhāvaṅkataṁ āyatiṁ🔽anuppādadhammaṁ, yopissa pemā doso jāyati sopissa pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato
analyzed: diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati yam pissa pemā pema  jāyati tam pissa pahīnam hoti ucchinna mūlam tālāvatthukatam an abhāvaṅkatam āyati  yaḥ pissa doso jāyati saḥ apissa pahīnaḥ hoti ucchinna mūlo tālā vatthu kato
translated: having realized it for himself with direct knowledge, the affection that arose in him because of his lust🔽has been abandoned, its root destroyed, made like a palmyra stump, deprived of the conditions of development, not destined for future arising. The aversion that arose in him because of his aversion

original: anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṁ anuppādadhammo,🔽yampissa dosā pemaṁ jāyati tampissa pahīnaṁ hoti ucchinnamūlaṁ tālāvatthukataṁ anabhāvaṅkataṁ
analyzed: an abhāvaṅkataḥ āyatim an uppāda dhammaḥ  yam pissa dosā pemam jāyati tam pissa pahīnam hoti ucchinna mūlam tālāvatthukatam
translated: has been abandoned, its root destroyed, made like a palmyra stump, deprived of the conditions of development, not destined for future arising.🔽The affection that arose in him because of his aversion has been abandoned, its root destroyed, made like a palmyra stump, deprived of the conditions of development, not destined for future arising. The aversion that arose in him because of his aversion

original: āyatiṁ anuppādadhammaṁ, yopissa dosā doso jāyati sopissa pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo
analyzed: āyatim an uppāda dhamma yaḥ pissa dosā dosaḥ jāyati saḥ upissa pahīnaḥ hoti ucchinna mūlo
translated: has been abandoned, its root destroyed, made like a palmyra stump, deprived of the conditions of development, not destined for future arising.

original: tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṁ anuppādadhammo.
analyzed: tālāvatthukataḥ an abhāvaṅkataḥ āyatim an uppāda dhammo
translated: it is not subject to arising, subject to passing away, subject to destruction.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu neva usseneti na paṭiseneti na dhūpāyati na pajjalati na sampajjhāyati.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave bhikkhu na iva usseneti na paṭiseneti na dhūpāyati na pajjalati na sampajjhāyati
translated: This is called a monk who neither smokes nor smolders nor flames up.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu usseneti?
analyzed: kathaṃca bhikkhave bhikkhu ussenā iti
translated: And how does a monk smoke?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rūpaṁ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṁ vā attānaṁ, attani vā rūpaṁ, rūpasmiṁ vā attānaṁ;🔽vedanaṁ attato samanupassati, vedanāvantaṁ vā attānaṁ, attani vā vedanaṁ, vedanāya vā attānaṁ;
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu rūpam attataḥ samanupassati rūpavantam vā attāna attani vā rūpa rūpasmin vā attāna  vedanam attataḥ samanupassati vedanāvantam vā attāna attani vā vedana vedanāya vā attāna
translated: It’s when a monk regards form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.🔽He regards feeling as self, self as having feeling, feeling in self, or self in feeling.

original: saññaṁ attato samanupassati, saññāvantaṁ vā attānaṁ, attani vā saññaṁ, saññāya vā attānaṁ;
analyzed: saññam attataḥ samanupassati saññāvantam vā attāna attani vā sañña saññāya vā attāna
translated: He regards perception as self, self as having perception, perception in self, or self in perception.

original: saṅkhāre attato samanupassati, saṅkhāravantaṁ vā attānaṁ, attani vā saṅkhāre, saṅkhāresu vā attānaṁ;
analyzed: saṅkhāre attataḥ samanupassati saṅkhāravantam vā attāna attani vā saṅkhāre saṅkhāresu vā attāna
translated: He regards volitional formations as self, self as having volitional formations, volitional formations in self, or self in volitional formations.

original: viññāṇaṁ attato samanupassati, viññāṇavantaṁ vā attānaṁ, attani vā viññāṇaṁ, viññāṇasmiṁ vā attānaṁ.
analyzed: viññāṇam attataḥ samanupassati viññāṇavantam vā attāna attani vā viññāṇa viññāṇasmin vā attāna
translated: He regards consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu usseneti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu ussenā iti
translated: That’s how a monk is one who slumbers.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na usseneti?
analyzed: kathaṃca bhikkhave bhikkhu na ussenā iti
translated: “And how is a monk not one who slumbers?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na rūpaṁ attato samanupassati, na rūpavantaṁ vā attānaṁ, na attani vā rūpaṁ, na rūpasmiṁ vā attānaṁ;🔽na vedanaṁ attato samanupassati, na vedanāvantaṁ vā attānaṁ, na attani vā vedanaṁ, na vedanāya vā attānaṁ;
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu na rūpam attataḥ samanupassati na rūpavantam vā attāna na attani vā rūpa na rūpasmin vā attāna  na vedanam attataḥ samanupassati na vedanāvantam vā attāna na attani vā vedana na vedanāya vā attāna
translated: There is the case where a monk does not regard form as self, self as possessing form, form as in self, or self as in form.🔽He does not regard feeling as self, self as possessing feeling, feeling as in self, or self as in feeling.

original: na saññaṁ attato samanupassati, na saññāvantaṁ vā attānaṁ, na attani vā saññaṁ, na saññāya vā attānaṁ;
analyzed: na saññam attataḥ samanupassati na saññāvantam vā attāna na attani vā sañña na saññāya vā attāna
translated: He does not regard perception as self, self as possessing perception, perception as in self, or self as in perception.

original: na saṅkhāre attato samanupassati, na saṅkhāravantaṁ vā attānaṁ, na attani vā saṅkhāre, na saṅkhāresu vā attānaṁ;
analyzed: na saṅkhāre attataḥ samanupassati na saṅkhāravantam vā attāna na attani vā saṅkhāre na saṅkhāresu vā attāna
translated: He does not regard fabrications as self, self as possessing fabrications, fabrications as in self, or self as in fabrications.

original: na viññāṇaṁ attato samanupassati, na viññāṇavantaṁ vā attānaṁ, na attani vā viññāṇaṁ, na viññāṇasmiṁ vā attānaṁ.
analyzed: na viññāṇam attataḥ samanupassati na viññāṇavantam vā attāna na attani vā viññāṇa na viññāṇasmin vā attāna
translated: He does not regard consciousness as self, self as possessing consciousness, consciousness as in self, or self as in consciousness.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na usseneti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na ussena iti
translated: That’s how a monk is not one who slumbers.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭiseneti?
analyzed: kathaṃca bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭiseneti
translated: And how does a monk retaliate?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkosantaṁ paccakkosati, rosantaṁ paṭirosati, bhaṇḍantaṁ paṭibhaṇḍati.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu akkosantam paccakkosati rosantam paṭirosati bhaṇḍantam paṭibhaṇḍati
translated: Here, when abused, a monk abuses in return; when scolded, he scolds in return; when angered, he angers in return; when beaten, he beats in return.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭiseneti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭiseneti
translated: That’s how a monk retaliates.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na paṭiseneti?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu na paṭiseneti
translated: And how does a monk not retaliate?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkosantaṁ na paccakkosati, rosantaṁ na paṭirosati, bhaṇḍantaṁ na paṭibhaṇḍati.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu akkosantam na paccakkosati rosantam na paṭirosati bhaṇḍantam na paṭibhaṇḍati
translated: Here, when abused, a monk doesn’t abuse in return; when scolded, he doesn’t scold in return; when angered, he doesn’t anger in return; when beaten, he doesn’t beat in return.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na paṭiseneti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na paṭiseneti
translated: That’s how a monk doesn’t retaliate.

analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu dhūpāyati  asmi iti bhikkhave sati itthasmi iti hoti evasmi iti hoti aññathā asmi iti hoti asasmi iti  hoti satasmi iti hoti santi hoti ittham santi hoti evam santi hoti aññathā santi

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhūpāyati.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu dhūpāyati
translated: It is in such a way, monks, that a monk does not smoke.

analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu na dhūpāyati
translated: And how, monks, does a monk not blaze?

translated: ‘I am’ not being, ‘I am this’ is not, ‘I am like this’ is not, ‘I am otherwise’ is not,🔽‘I am not’ is not, ‘I am possessed of’ is not, ‘I am possessed of this’ is not, ‘I am possessed of like this’ is not,🔽‘I am possessed of otherwise’ is not, ‘I am possessed of even this’ is not, ‘I am possessed of even like this’ is not,

analyzed: bhavissanti na hoti evam bhavissanti na hoti aññathā bhavissanti na hoti
translated: ‘I am possessed of even otherwise’ is not, ‘I will be’ is not, ‘I will be this’ is not, ‘I will be like this’ is not,

analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na dhūpāyati 🔽kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu pajjalati
translated: ‘I will be otherwise’ is not.

analyzed: iminā asmi iti bhikkhave sati iminā itthasmi iti hoti iminā evasmi iti hoti iminā  aññathā asmi iti hoti iminā asasmi iti hoti iminā satasmi iti hoti iminā santi hoti iminā  ittham santi hoti iminā evam santi hoti iminā aññathā santi hoti iminā apiha
translated: With ‘I am this’ being the case, there is ‘I am such,’ there is ‘I am otherwise,’ there is ‘I am this,’ there is ‘I am that,’ there is ‘I am here,’ there is ‘I am there,’ there is ‘I am both here and there,’ there is ‘I am neither here nor there.’🔽With ‘I am this’ being the case, there is ‘I am such,’ there is ‘I am otherwise,’ there is ‘I am this,’ there is ‘I am that,’ there is ‘I am here,’ there is ‘I am there,’ there is ‘I am both here and there,’ there is ‘I am neither here nor there.’🔽With ‘I am this’ being the case, there is ‘I am such,’ there is ‘I am otherwise,’ there is ‘I am this,’ there is ‘I am that,’ there is ‘I am here,’ there is ‘I am there,’ there is ‘I am both here and there,’ there is ‘I am neither here nor there.’

original: santi hoti, iminā apihaṁ itthaṁ santi hoti, iminā apihaṁ evaṁ santi hoti, iminā apihaṁ🔽aññathā santi hoti, iminā bhavissanti hoti, iminā itthaṁ bhavissanti hoti, iminā
analyzed: santi hoti iminā apihaṃ ittham santi hoti iminā apihaṃ evam santi hoti iminā apiha  aññathā santi hoti iminā bhavissanti hoti iminā ittham bhavissanti hoti iminā
translated: With ‘I am this’ being the case, there is ‘I am such,’ there is ‘I am otherwise,’ there is ‘I am this,’ there is ‘I am that,’ there is ‘I am here,’ there is ‘I am there,’ there is ‘I am both here and there,’ there is ‘I am neither here nor there.’

original: evaṁ bhavissanti hoti, iminā aññathā bhavissanti hoti.🔽Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pajjalati.🔽Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na pajjalati?
analyzed: evam bhavissanti hoti iminā aññathā bhavissanti hoti  evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu pajjalati  kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu na pajjalati
translated: With ‘I am this’ being the case, there is ‘I am such,’ there is ‘I am otherwise,’ there is ‘I am this,’ there is ‘I am that,’ there is ‘I am here,’ there is ‘I am there,’ there is ‘I am both here and there,’ there is ‘I am neither here nor there.’🔽With ‘I am this’ being the case, there is ‘I am such,’ there is ‘I am otherwise,’ there is ‘I am this,’ there is ‘I am that,’ there is ‘I am here,’ there is ‘I am there,’ there is ‘I am both here and there,’ there is ‘I am neither here nor there.’

original: Iminā asmīti, bhikkhave, asati iminā itthasmīti na hoti, iminā evaṁsmīti na hoti,
analyzed: iminā asmi iti bhikkhave asati iminā itthasmi iti na hoti iminā evasmi iti na hoti
translated: With ‘I am this’ being the case, there is ‘I am such,’ there is ‘I am otherwise,’ there is ‘I am this,’ there is ‘I am that,’ there is ‘I am here,’ there is ‘I am there,’ there is ‘I am both here and there,’ there is ‘I am neither here nor there.’🔽With

original: iminā aññathāsmīti na hoti, iminā asasmīti na hoti, iminā satasmīti na hoti, iminā🔽santi na hoti, iminā itthaṁ santi na hoti, iminā evaṁ santi na hoti, iminā aññathā🔽santi na hoti, iminā apihaṁ santi na hoti, iminā apihaṁ itthaṁ santi na hoti, iminā
analyzed: iminā aññathā asmi iti na hoti iminā asasmi iti na hoti iminā satasmi iti na hoti iminā  santi na hoti iminā ittham santi na hoti iminā evam santi na hoti iminā aññathā  santi na hoti iminā apiham santi na hoti iminā apiham ittham santi na hoti iminā
translated: In this way, ‘I am otherwise’ does not exist. In this way, ‘I am not’ does not exist. In this way, ‘I am’ does not exist.🔽In this way, ‘They exist’ does not exist. In this way, ‘They exist in such a way’ does not exist. In this way, ‘They exist in this way’ does not exist. In this way, ‘They exist otherwise’ does not exist.

original: apihaṁ evaṁ santi na hoti, iminā apihaṁ aññathā santi na hoti, iminā bhavissanti🔽na hoti, iminā itthaṁ bhavissanti na hoti, iminā evaṁ bhavissanti na hoti, iminā
analyzed: apiham evam santi na hoti iminā apiham aññathā santi na hoti iminā bhavissanti  na hoti iminā ittham bhavissanti na hoti iminā evam bhavissanti na hoti iminā
translated: In this way, ‘They exist somewhere’ does not exist. In this way, ‘They exist somewhere in such a way’ does not exist. In this way, ‘They exist somewhere in this way’ does not exist. In this way, ‘They exist somewhere otherwise’ does not exist.

original: aññathā bhavissanti na hoti.
analyzed: aññathā bhavissanti na hoti
translated: In this way, ‘They will exist’ does not exist. In this way, ‘They will exist in such a way’ does not exist. In this way, ‘They will exist in this way’ does not exist. In this way, ‘They will exist otherwise’ does not exist.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na pajjalati.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na pajjalati
translated: In this way, monks, a monk does not burn.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajjhāyati?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu sampajjhāyati
translated: And how, monks, does a monk smoulder?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno asmimāno pahīno na hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṁ anuppādadhammo.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ asmimānaḥ pahīnaḥ na hoti ucchinna mūlaḥ tālāvatthukataḥ anabhāvaṅkataḥ āyatim an uppāda dhammo
translated: Here, monks, a monk has not given up the conceit ‘I am’, has not cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it so that it is no more subject to future arising.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajjhāyati.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu sampajjhāyati
translated: In this way, monks, a monk smoulders.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na sampajjhāyati?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu na sampajjhāyati
translated: And how does a monk not get burned?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno asmimāno pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṁ anuppādadhammo.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ asmimānaḥ pahīnaḥ hoti ucchinna mūlaḥ tālāvatthukataḥ anabhāvaṅkataḥ āyatim an uppāda dhammo
translated: It’s when a monk has given up identity view, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na sampajjhāyatī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na sampajjhāyati iti
translated: That’s how a monk doesn’t get burned.”

translated: There is the case where someone fabricates an unoffending bodily fabrication, an unoffending verbal fabrication, an unoffending mental fabrication.🔽Having fabricated an unoffending bodily fabrication, an unoffending verbal fabrication, an unoffending mental fabrication, he is reborn in an unoffending world.

analyzed: tam enam abyābajjham lokam upapannam samānam abyābajjhā phassā phusanti
